column13: Read to irritate people. I love that.
column14: We didn't have a TV and also, in the summers we spent a month on a small island about 3/4 of a mile long. This is how you come to enjoy fine writing. Hemingway wasn't politically correct. So I'll stick up for him. Also because he wrote so beautifully. If you don't appreciate it, okay, but give this book a chance and shut off all your electronic gizmos, let the grass grow, smoke a doobie, relax and give up on that woman you're jonesin for, etc. And also, even though I think Hemingway loved cats, I bet he didn't like them when he was either reading, writing, remembering, trying to think, cleaning his gun, composing a Dear Johnette letter, smoking a Cuban, scratching behind his ear, or drinking heavily. I just wish he had been able to find some degree of happiness and not blow his head off. He was a wonderfully creative person who could make you believe his fiction and his nonfiction alike. That's what it's all about. Believability. Same with good films and if you can get a woman to believe you, you must be Houdini or something. More power to you.

column13: My First Hemingway Novel Was Worth It!
column14: This was my first Ernest Hemingway novel. I bought it because it was recommended and is a classic.  Now I understand why Ernest Hemingway is considered such a great writer. His short staccato style of writing about a group of friends traveling through Spain and the whole feeling of that time period is just so amazing. I felt like I wanted to be with that group of people, I wanted to know them. Truly a great way to start reading Hemingway!

column13: I really have tried to like his books
column14:
Ernest Hemingway – sigh. I tried. I really have tried to like his books, hence the renewed foray into this one. But I just cannot bring myself to feel anything but boredom when reading his stories. Either I’m not sophisticated enough to understand one of our literary greats, or Hemingway is the proverbial emperor without any clothes, and no one dares point out how lacking he really is, for fear of being called ignorant.

The Sun Also Rises is not a bad story per se. A bunch of World War I veterans living in Paris and then venturing into Spain to witness a bullfight, with a complicated love triangle – or rather, a love rectangle or even love pentagon, if such a thing exists – woven into the tale. But that already sounds a lot more exciting than what the book delivers. It might have been a good story, but it just wasn’t. Let me count the ways:

The narrative: I know Hemingway gets praised for his stripped bare and plain storytelling, without much embellishment, but I found it totally uninspired. There are passages that go like this: I went to the hotel. I got a room with a balcony overlooking the rooftops. I took a shower and went to lunch. I ordered a bottle of wine. Then I walked up the street to the ocean. The tide was about halfway out the beach… (this is not an actual quote, I listened to the audio version of the book and so had trouble getting exact quotes, but trust me, it wasn’t all that different).

The characters: I mean, how much drinking and eating and sleeping off your hangovers can you do? I know these are supposed to be the characters of the lost generation after WWI, but still – all they ever do is go look for a bar, order drinks, and more drinks, and more drinks, and eventually go home and sleep it off. Hemingway spends a lot of time describing which kinds of drinks they are, in intricate detail. But we never really learn as much about the characters as we might, given the right dialog, because all the dialog is wasted on the drink orders and some very superficial conversation. In fact, I liken Hemingway to a travel blogger, a not very good one. He describes what’s going on around him, all the new and exciting sights he sees – like the bullfight, the only time the story comes to life a little bit – but there is no real growth in the characters throughout the story.

The plot: Where is the plot? So Brett, the narrator’s love, is having affairs left and right and thereby pissing off a good number of people. Through most of the story I was waiting for some kind of climax, thinking one of her spurned lovers would end up killing the latest one, and if that had happened, the story – though boring through most of the book – might have redeemed itself a little bit. But no, nothing happens – sorry, should have given you a spoiler alert – and everything just sort of fizzles out at the end. There is nothing for the reader to cling to, other than a bunch of characters adrift aimlessly and talking to each other while consuming an ungodly amount of wine and harder liquor.

The style: There isn’t much style at all. There are no sentences you want to go back and re-read, no poetic passages, no big insights into human nature, and, most lacking to me, no foreshadowing whatsoever. It really does read like a teenager’s diary going “and then this happened, and then we went there, and after that…” I couldn’t tell you for the life of me what Hemingway’s “voice” is. Other than perhaps being able to recognize his voice by virtue of being bored to death whenever I open one of his books.

I also would like to add that I find the writing in this story vaguely anti-Semitic. It was probably very common in those times to make the kinds of comments about Jews that his characters repeatedly make, but after a while it grated on me. It was less offensive to me than it felt obsolete, if that makes sense.

I can honestly say thatthe only reason I finished the book was that it was fairly short and I was still waiting for my new library book at the time. When that arrived – Donna Tart’s “A Secret History” - I breathed a huge sigh of relief to have a “real” story again, one that captivated me from the first sentence and where my mind was whirling with infinite possibilities as to how it might unfold.

If The Sun Also Rises was written by one of the many expat bloggers I follow, I would have stopped reading much faster. Hemingway seems to get the benefit of the doubt due to his name alone, but I for one am done with him and his ramblings.the only reason I finished the book was that it was fairly short and I was still waiting for my new library book at the time. When that arrived – Donna Tart’s “A Secret History” - I breathed a huge sigh of relief to have a “real” story again, one that captivated me from the first sentence and where my mind was whirling with infinite possibilities as to how it might unfold.

column13: A strong debut but not Hemingway's best
column14:
The Sun Also Rises is apparently viewed by some as Hemingway's greatest novel. I disagree. Hemingway himself has gone on record as saying that he didn't really know how to write a compelling novel at the time this book was published (I'm paraphrasing). That said, this novel is a quitly moving indication of where the author's style would go when put to better use.

The subject matter is interesting but the plot is a bit meandering. Things get more interesting in the latter third of the book but if you're not a fan of poeple sitting around waxing existential, then you're not going to find much here. However, as usual, Hemingway's description of nature and the local Spanish culture is absolutely beautiful.
My first hemingway book and i loved it.
A must read because of the talent of Ernest Hemingway. this is engrossing and engaging.

column13: Loved The Old Man and the Sea and wanted to ...
column14: Loved The Old Man and the Sea and wanted to continue reading Hemingway. This was not a good book to me, but it will not stop me from reading other stories by him.

column13: Slow pace but engaging dialogue and description
column14: Hemingway knows how to place the reader in the moment. Even if it is just a view of a rainy street with a restaurant in the back, he will pick out details that will get far more than the sight across. He will illuminate the mood and the thoughts of the people, all without explicitly saying so. This "unfolding" of meaning in his writing is beautiful to read. The pace, however, is slow. Readers coming from Dan Brown novels may yawn a few times before appreciating the depth of writing found here. There is lots to take from these underlying meanings found in his work. For me, I now have two urges: to go fishing and, more importantly, to get to know my friends and the people around me better.
Everyone should read this book.

"The Sun also Rises" is part travelogue; part chronicle:  We went here; We went there.  We did this; we did that.  The novel contains mostly banal dialogue that does little to advance the plot or define the characters.  Brett is an under developed character who appears too infrequently in the book.  What is her motivation?  What makes her tick?  As opposed to Bill who is on almost ever page and is as dull as dish water.  The novel could be called a primer on 'how to become an alcoholic,'  Essentially, it is about a bunch of worthless, drifting characters going now
For school

I will start off by saying I am not a fan of Hemingway. Hence, even though I tried to give this book a chance, I still didn't care for it. The story revolves around a bunch of people with issues who sit around drinking and complaining about each other. There's not much action and what dialogue there is, and there is mostly dialogue, is so boring. The topics covered are all small talk, nothing deep, meaningful, or profound. I'm a person who hates small talk, and that's what this book is made out of. Most people want to read a book and escape their boredom, but Hemingway, and this novel of his in particular, just amplifies your own boredom. I know of people who love this book, so I know I'm in the minority with this opinion, but I have given my reasons for my dislike of it. It simply bores me and I wouldn't wish that feeling on anyone.

column13: "The things that happened could only have happened during a fiesta"
column14:
I read this after a visit to Pamplona, where Hemingway is a Big Name. I hadn't been too struck on previous works of his, so began dubiously.
This novel is narrated by one Jake Barnes, a young American, and his 'gang' of friends, notably Lady Brett Ashley and her hard-drinking fiance. These 'bright young things' have been damaged by WW1 - Jake (like just about all the men) is in love with Brett, but has been rendered impotent. She, meanwhile, seems emotionally scarred: we learn in a conversation that her true love died during the War, while she served as a V.A.D. in a hospital.
Opening in Paris, where life is one round of alcoholic nights out and - for Brett - a succession of meaningless assignations with men - the group move off to take in Pamplona for some fishing and the annual fiesta and bullfights. I got quite caught up in the book at this point, thinking I knew what was going to happen to this little group of people among whom passions were aroused, echoing the descriptions of the bullfights (I was totally wrong!)
A book that grew on me, despite having a largely unlikeable cast of characters. Hemingway brings the atmosphere of Spain to life.
Good Hemingway reading. His time in Europe during the twenties.

column13: A Required Reading Book (for some reason)
column14: To be honest, I had to read this for school, so my review may be a bit biased. All in all this is a wonderful book, if you can get past the semi-bland writing style. (I nearly fell asleep several times while reading it - bad sign.) Hope you enjoy it better than I did!

Classic. Useful to read with the iceberg theory in mind- there is a lot going on that isn't explicitly on the page. I have to admit I found the long stretches of countryside descriptions dry, but they are interesting as a representation of Jake's state of mind and in contrast to the narration when he is alone in his bedroom at night. After you read it, check out some of the context for the writing and publishing of the book on the wikipedia article. Interesting stuff.

It's amazing what time does to all of us. Trite, but true. When I was sixteen, Hemingway loomed in my consciousness like an artistic holy grail. This novel, along with another diminished "titan" The Old Man and the Sea, occupied central positions as the great writer's crown jewels.

Reading it again for the first time in many years proved revelatory. I didn't like these people. It isn't essential that I'd want to arm wrestle Jake or whatever, but I do require a compelling interest in the lives of fictional characters for a novel to stand up well. Travelogues, however well rendered, aren't a substitute for presenting three-dimensional human beings with at least a kernel of psychological complexity. Nor is there much romance past twenty-five in reading glamorized accounts of alcoholic dissipation. At least not if you know what's good for you.

The characters that challenge gender roles and troubled heroes are there too, I just didn't find the content matter particularly interesting.

This book broke boundaries in 1926 for it depicted a dissolute and pessimistic menagerie of writers drinking themselves into oblivion. The protagonist Jake Barnes is war wounded and lost his manliness, so the girl he loves humiliates him by treating him like a best pal, while she sleeps around various characters that come and go through out the story. The settings of Paris and Pamplona Spain provide a colourful back ground to that social menagerie. The running of the bulls and the bull fights of Pamplona act like an allegory to the sexuality of the menagerie. The metaphor is in the title, the sun sets on this dissolute and pessimistic menagerie therefore it rises elsewhere.

In the early twentieth century moderns went about breaking the moral codes and taboos of that society for the sake of their art. This book is of that stripe. In the early twenty first century that seems mundane and unimaginative. Hemingway is known for his pared down or simple style of writing. He can provoke the imagination to picture the scenes and follow the dialogue with few words. That being said I did get lost while meeting the characters in the first part of the book. It is considered literature and a important book from the twentieth century.

column13: Jake is still in love with Brett
column14: Hemmingway’s The Sun Also Rises shows the ideas of modernist art that rose after World War I. The book is a direct reflection of Hemmingway’s struggle to find meaning and the reason for existence. The main characters spend all their time drinking and dancing, trying to avoid the internal challenges they’re facing. Jake is still in love with Brett, but she refuses to be with him, causing him to question everything about life. Growing up we believe that love conquers all, so Jake is left confused and troubled about what he really knows. Hemmingway’s simplistic style of writing makes the book easy to read and understand, however I find it hard to relate to the story and its characters because of its cynical tone. I am a positive person so I have differing views than the characters and have a difficult time trying to understand their motives and actions. I’m still young and haven’t experienced life enough to make me question it, but Hemmingway has, and this is his opinion of the world after witnessing the destruction and horrors of war. It seems that Hemmingway has lost hope in the world, which isn’t the nicest thing to read about. But that’s what modernism is. It tells the truth no matter how unpleasant it is to hear. Realism before the war liked to make everything pretty and beautiful, but modernism isn’t afraid to show the ugliness that can occur. This book was beautifully written, but it wasn’t my favorite in content, merely because reading about the sadness of the world isn’t that enjoyable to me. It’s blunt and straight to the point, making its message extremely clear. I may not have been in love with this book, but there is no denying that Hemmingway is an incredible writer and there are few other authors that can match his skill and style.

column13: Interesting because it is Hemingway's first book.
column14:
I don't care what people say this is NOT a brilliant book-----but it does show a small trickle of promise.
The characters are worthless alcoholics, but they are interesting. The conversations, of which there is much,
is the talk of degenerates. But there is definitely a spark and the reader continues to read. The "nonstory"
is about several men who are good friends and love a party. There is one lovely girl. She too is less than admirable.
The site is Spain during a week long festival. There are excellent bull fight scenes. The characterization of these men
is complete, you would recognize them, but would tend to go in the opposite direction. They probably want to borrow money.
The festival FINALLY is over and everybody goes home, The End.

This is the most dull book I have ever read. After trying my hardest to read this thing for four days, I'm giving up at chapter five. It takes me twenty minutes to get through two pages, and not because I'm a slow reader, but because this book couldn't keep my attention if the words were bright green and flashing on the page. I tried to give it a fair shot, because, come on, it's Ernest Hemingway! That must mean it's good—or at least has some sort of substance—right? Wrong. Very, very wrong. This book is painfully boring and nothing more, which is really disappointing. I was drawn to this book after reading an enthralling excerpt from it somewhere, and I was led to believe it would be an interesting, intellectual, and insightful read. Perhaps it is for those odd few who could manage to finish a full sentence without having their attention grabbed elsewhere, but it wasn't for me.

Jake, the protagonist of this book, has no character to him; no beauty; all he does is cite his day in a tired tone and complain about Brett—who, by the way, is unbelievably annoying and strange. He has a few random friends which nobody really cares about and which he spends too much time with, and one of which he spent far too much time detailing the history of his boxing past in the opening chapter. (To be fair, that could be related to some event or another later on in the story, but I wouldn't know, obviously.) While I am mildly curious about Brett and Jake's past and the mysterious "injuries" Jake kept bringing up but not explaining, my curiosity doesn't extend far enough to get me through this book. Like I said, I gave it my best shot, but that's normally right where you can tell a book is a dud: when you have to put effort into reading it.

Despite the disappointingly lackluster quality of this book, I'll give Hemingway the benefit of the doubt and try out some of his other books. He's got to be a classic novelist for a reason, but this book sure isn't it.

column13: Characters Flat | Not Worth The Time
column14: There is not a single character in this entire book that is worn a damn. I generally like Hemmingway for his style and memorable characters. The style is here, but the characters in the book are flat, lacking moral courage, strength of character, and intellectual and moral virtue generally. It is not worth the time or effort to read.  If you love Hemmingway's style, then enjoy.

column13: An Insult to all who admire good writing.
column14:
Thank the maker I checked this book out at the library. What a total waste of money it would have been if I had bought it. Pure…utter….nonsense.

But, we must understand that Hemingway was 27 years old, immature, most likely drunk, and this novel was written in his very first year as a novel-writer.

This novel has thee worst dialog ever to grace a page. It is unnatural in every sense. It is contrived It is repetitive. It is just…plain….awful.

It’s as if Hemingway’s “mission statement” in writing this novel was to mention drinking wine, eating at a restaurant, being chauffeured about the town, and staying in posh hotels, at least five times…on…every….single….page.

There is no plot. The characters are as substance-less as they could get. Eat, drink, party, talk bad about others. Rinse and repeat.

My final issue is that I was prohibited from burning this book (so as not to inflict pain upon future readers.) The library might have had a problem with that.
Bought it for class, shipped semi-fast was exactly what I needed.

Hemingway's seminal work that established his style and his reputation. Unlike his other novels, this is a synthesis of his lifestyle at the time and the modernist writing style he aspired to. His effort at blending these is only somewhat successful.

It's tempting to look for allegorical meaning in the fishing, fiesta, and bull fighting. But the truth is probably simpler: that was Hemingway's life at the time and he was writing about what he knew. They do add some color to the story, but not much depth.

The characters are the strength of this novel, with each one exhibiting impotence when facing the headwinds of life. Cohn's boxing is his attempt to equip himself to face his struggles, but that turns out to be useless in his pursuit of his desires. Brett lurches from one cataclysm to another. Michael's life is in an irretrievable tailspin. Ironically, Jake, who is literally impotent, is probably best equipped to deal with circumstances, but his aspirations remain out of reach.

The resulting fatalistic tone evokes the Lost Generation of the 20's. Having lived through the world war, they lost interest in building a future, and instead found refuge in hedonistic excesses. Hemingway is successful in conveying that atmosphere. Ultimately though, The Sun Also Rises is most notable for the foundation it lays, serving as the basis for Hemingway's major works that followed.

column13: OMG! I know it's Hemingway... but ...
column14: OMG !  I know it's Hemingway...but this was awful!!!
I learned how to become a bitter alcoholic from this book.

My favorite modernist novelist is Virginia Woolf. Reading and re-reading her best known books, Mrs. Dalloway and To The Lighthouse, has taught me how to approach this genre, identifying distinctive themes and formulating reasonable and satisfying interpretations.

When Virginia Woolf, in her own beautiful prose, employs her characters to unself-consciously manufacture social reality, they do so using the tools available at the time: a composite of social conventions and cultural artifacts that are innately transitory, though they feel undeniably timeless and unmistakably real. She proceeds in a way that is discernible to careful readers but doesn't smash it in their faces. There is no doubt that life is inherently meaningless, interpretable only through the meanings that her characters create in ways that are taken for granted and only very subtly evident.

We also see the effects of the catastrophe that was World War I, and the technology-intensive, rapid transformation of social relations that accompanied and followed the War. In time, the world of culturally shared meanings becomes quite different from traditional beliefs and practices. Still socially constructed and mutable, they constitute a new reality, as seemingly reliable and true as that which came before, an epistemological transformation of commonsense that Woolf captures with elegance and insight.

It would be foolish and perversely doctrinaire to expect Hemingway's modernist fiction, as manifest in The Sun Also Rises, to mimic the work of Virginia Woolf. However, while she manages to deal with modernist themes and issues with remarkable literary skill, Hemingway, sadly, can't seem to pull it off. His ostensibly lean and masculine prose too often strikes me as just plodding indifference. Maybe even a lazy caricature of himself.

The themes of modernism are there, more or less, but they exhibit themselves with uncaring decadence and dramatized brutality. With occasional ancillary exceptions, the characters are vulgarly obvious aesthetes, frenetic seekers of meaning and purpose that just isn't there and that they don't know how to create. Their levels of chronic self-absorption run deep and disclose nothing to grab hold of. These are characters who seem incapable of coming to terms with the world as they find it, and perhaps consequently are obsessively concerned with affectations and gossipy exchanges over drinks of various kinds in a seemingly inexhaustible collection of cafe's. They bring to mind the aimless fidgeting of hyper-active children.

The narrator and protagonist, Jake, is a determinedly solicitous cipher, everyone's best friend, who comes to us out of nowhere and has no life apart from his "crowd" of privileged characters. Perhaps a bit more abstemious and a bit less conspicuously aimless that the rest, his war wounds have left him helpless in crucial ways. One wonders just what Jake, and for that matter the rest of the "crowd," is seeking beyond comfortable idleness and, eventually, the excitement generated by artfully staged and savagely manipulated blood sports such as bull fighting.

Hemingway's characters seem to be devoid of insight, blinded by the modern world with its limitless but transitory possibilities. They chat about going to England, South America, the U.S. and anywhere else that might occur to them, but they have no compelling reason not to just stay where they are. They could write books, and some do, though it's unclear that quality rather than the familial connections of the wealthy gets the occasional book into print. Besides, what would they write about? It seems that all they know is each other, and their conversational exchanges are typically so tedious and banal that knowing each other is not knowing very much. Yes, the fact that their lives are fraught with the tedious and the banal could be the basis for a novel, and perhaps that isHemingway's point, but if it is, he made it in a tedious and banal way.

The characters, moreover, are little able to appreciate the beauty in much of anything unless it takes the painfully brutal form of a bull bred for fighting goring an awkward, defenseless steer in just exactly the right way. The steer was put in the ring to give the bull something to do, a diversion, the same empty purpose that bullfighting itself serves for its audience. Something sufficiently ugly, merciless, and unforgiving to penetrate their protective shells of effete indifference. Ironic that the responses of Hemingway's characters of privilege, with the exception of Robert Cohn, whom the others tolerate but nothing more, is so much like that of the rural peasants attending their annual festival. Diverted from ennui or diverted from hard work and hardship, apparently there's not much difference.

Robert Cohn, moreover is a mystery. Oddly, this pathetic hanger-on is the only member of the privileged herd that has mastered a blood sport, the sort of attainment on which Hemingway placed an inordinately high value. But Cohn's skill as a boxer is of no value when it comes to getting what he really wants. His restraint in tolerating the vicious taunts of Mike and occasionally some of the others, renders his physical prowess pointless. Besides, Cohn lacks the passionate killer instinct that is the hallmark of a worthy blood sport practitioner. One wonders why he's there, doing little or nothing but absorbing punishment. Certainly the mercurial and spoiled Brett is not going to turn her amorous attention toward him, resuming their long dead affair.

There is a great deal of descriptive material in this novel, covering cities, villages, cathedrals, distinctively Spanish mountainous terrain, fruitfully flourishing wheat fields, the skin tones of peasants and the wealthy, and a good deal more. But Hemingway's treatments of even the most inspiring and colorful natural phenomena and man-made artifacts are pretty conventional, lacking in interesting detail, unless a matador is killing a bull. Perhaps this limitation is one reason why I found myself longing for a narrative. Modernism is averse to narratives, unnatural patterns of temporal coherence that introduce meaning that is nothing more than an imposition, a conceit that prevents us from seeing the world as it is. The Sun Also Rises is so substantively sparse, however, that the absence of a narrative leaves us groping for a clue as to why it was written.

We live in a world that is cruel and brutal by its very nature. Why we feel the need to introduce dramatized exaggerations that yield still more pain and lethality and call it an occasion for a waspish game of bridge or a week-long drunken festival topped off by the slaughter of bulls is a mystery. The psychological and physical savagery that we control is of our own making, but so what?

My favorite novel is The Old Man and the Sea, a book of rare beauty and infinite wisdom. Some hold that Hemingway would not have won a Nobel prize without it. Perhaps in his earlier work, The Sun Also Rises included, Hemingway was developing his art, discovering how to write like a genius. Otherwise, I can't think of a good reason for writing something so pointlessly empty as this novel. It occurred to me that if an unknown had submitted The Sun Also Rises to a published it would have been quickly rejected.nt, but if it is, he made it in a tedious and banal way.

The characters, moreover, are little able to appreciate the beauty in much of anything unless it takes the painfully brutal form of a bull bred for fighting goring an awkward, defenseless steer in just exactly the right way. The steer was put in the ring to give the bull something to do, a diversion, the same empty purpose that bullfighting itself serves for its audience. Something sufficiently ugly, merciless, and unforgiving to penetrate their protective shells of effete indifference. Ironic that the responses of Hemingway's characters of privilege, with the exception of Robert Cohn, whom the others tolerate but nothing more, is so much like that of the rural peasants attending their annual festival. Diverted from ennui or diverted from hard work and hardship, apparently there's not much difference.

Robert Cohn, moreover is a mystery. Oddly, this pathetic hanger-on is the only member of the privileged herd that has mastered a blood sport, the sort of attainment on which Hemingway placed an inordinately high value. But Cohn's skill as a boxer is of no value when it comes to getting what he really wants. His restraint in tolerating the vicious taunts of Mike and occasionally some of the others, renders his physical prowess pointless. Besides, Cohn lacks the passionate killer instinct that is the hallmark of a worthy blood sport practitioner. One wonders why he's there, doing little or nothing but absorbing punishment. Certainly the mercurial and spoiled Brett is not going to turn her amorous attention toward him, resuming their long dead affair.

There is a great deal of descriptive material in this novel, covering cities, villages, cathedrals, distinctively Spanish mountainous terrain, fruitfully flourishing wheat fields, the skin tones of peasants and the wealthy, and a good deal more. But Hemingway's treatments of even the most inspiring and colorful natural phenomena and man-made artifacts are pretty conventional, lacking in interesting detail, unless a matador is killing a bull. Perhaps this limitation is one reason why I found myself longing for a narrative. Modernism is averse to narratives, unnatural patterns of temporal coherence that introduce meaning that is nothing more than an imposition, a conceit that prevents us from seeing the world as it is. The Sun Also Rises is so substantively sparse, however, that the absence of a narrative leaves us groping for a clue as to why it was written.

Why we feel the need to introduce dramatized exaggerations that yield still more pain and lethality and call it an occasion for a waspish game of bridge or a week-long drunken festival topped off by the slaughter of bulls is a mystery. The psychological and physical savagery that we control is of our own making, but so what?

My favorite novel is The Old Man and the Sea, a book of rare beauty and infinite wisdom. Perhaps in his earlier work, The Sun Also Rises included, Hemingway was developing his art, discovering how to write like a genius. Otherwise, I can't think of a good reason for writing something so pointlessly empty as this novel.
a classic. life in Europe as bigoted in 1924 as now. Read this Hemingway as a disquisition on various kinds of prejudices. Then it achieves a whole new light.

Ah, Hemingway. Such a writer!!! I have passed this book along to friends who were anxious to read it . Good condition and fast shipping
Excellent.
My absolute favorite novel.

Hemingway is a legend for a reason.  In this book in particular, he shows how he had his fingers perfectly on the pulse of the Lost Generation.  His characters are very realistic, as they should be, since they're based on real people, and the events of the book based on real events.  You could consider that a knock against his originality if you wanted to; I don't.  Even though you know the story is going to end with mass tragedy (it is Hemingway, after all), the road there is fascinating and the book is worth a read.  It's one of those books where you don't simply read it, think "That was nice," and put it down; it gives you things to ponder, and makes you think about your own priorities and worldview assumptions, if you're into that kind of thing.

Written in 1926, Hemingway's characters are part of the 'lost generation' - those young people so emotionally damaged by WW1 that they are left drifting and purposeless, leading lives of dissolute recklessness. We first meet our narrator, Jake Barnes, in Paris, where he works as a journalist. Jake and Lady Brett Ashley love one another, but Jake has been left impotent by a war injury, and Brett is not the kind of woman who could be happy in a relationship that didn't offer her sexual fulfilment. So Brett embarks on a string of sexual adventures, usually with friends of Jake's, while Jake drinks. And drinks. And drinks. Actually, so does Brett. And by about a third of the way through the book, I was toying with the idea of knocking back three bottles of wine, a couple of brandies, and an absinthe or two myself. (But then the 'lost generation' usually has that effect on me - privileged, feckless wasters living off Daddy's money, and blaming their dissipated lifestyles on the war. Poor ex-soldiers, of course, just had to go home, get a job and get on with things - they couldn't afford to get 'lost' in Paris or Spain. Poverty is such a great sat-nav.)

When Paris begins to run low on alcohol, Jake and a loose group of friends and acquaintances, including Brett and her fiancé, make their way to Pamplona in Spain for the annual bull-fighting fiesta. There is a lot of alcohol available in Spain, of all different kinds, and this, together with the fact that every man in the party has either slept with Brett or wants to, leads to lots of macho posturing - not unlike the more formalised posturing that takes place between the matador and the bull. Surprisingly enough, Lady Brett seems to quite like matadors...

Hemingway's writing style is an odd mix of sometimes overly simplistic prose with occasional passages of real beauty. Some of the dialogue is mind-numbingly trite - repetitive and dull - and he gets fixated on details from time to time, like how much a bottle of wine cost or what each person ate. I tired very quickly of the endless descriptions of binge-drinking and drunken quarrelling. But some of the descriptions are excellent - the dusty journey to Pamplona, the passengers met by chance en route all merge to become a strikingly vivid picture of a particular place and time. As they all sit around drinking in Pamplona, I felt I could see the various cafés and bars clearly, almost smell them. The interactions between the ex-pats and the natives are brilliantly portrayed, particularly the growing disapproval from the real aficionados when Brett's behaviour begins to threaten the traditions of the bullfight. And as for the arena itself, I found I was unexpectedly fascinated by his depiction of the rituals around the running of the bulls and the bullfighting.

The same patchiness applies to the characterisation. I'm not at all sure what he was trying to achieve with Lady Brett's character - but I'm pretty sure he didn't achieve it. She didn't come over as a real person to me at all. Her permanent drunkenness and ridiculously promiscuous behaviour may have made many men want to sleep with her, but the idea that they all fell in love with her was a stretch too far. I felt as if she was a puppet rather than a character, her behaviour merely a device to provide reasons for strains and tensions to develop amongst the group of men.

I'm sure screeds have been written about the blatant anti-Semitism in the book and I must say I wasn't overwhelmingly thrilled by his stereotyping of his Scottish character either. But honestly both characterisations seemed to me more like lazy regurgitations of racial caricatures than any kind of active racism, and it was the 1920s, so no doubt they seem more shocking to us now than they would have been then. In fact, I wasn't at all sure that he wasn't attempting to gently ridicule the prevailing anti-Semitism of his time - but if that was his intention, by leaving it ambiguous, again I feel he failed.

However, I feel we get to know Jake well and some of the others come over as fairly well-rounded. There is a good deal of subtlety in the way he slowly reveals Jake to us as the most resilient of them all - the one who is physically damaged, but with the most emotional strength in the end. The whole 'there's more than one way to be masculine' message may seem obvious in retrospect but it's actually fed through in a gradual and almost understated way, and I felt I only really saw what Hemingway was doing as I looked back at the book after finishing.

I'm going to confess that in the end the book impressed me considerably more than I expected. Despite my many criticisms, I found it an absorbing read that drew me into the world Hemingway was describing and made it a believable one; and my appreciation for it actually grew in the few days after I had finished reading it. I feel that it needs to be approached like an impressionist painting - when you're close enough to see the detail it all looks a bit messy and it's hard to make out the picture. But stand back a bit and the details recede - the constant descriptions of drunkenness, the repetitiveness, the banality of the dialogue - and the picture that emerges of a damaged man metaphorically rising from the ashes through a kind of examination of maleness is really quite compelling after all. 4½ stars for me, so rounded up.

NB This book was provided for review by the publisher, Scribner.ambiguous, again I feel he failed.

Excellent book!! I had forgotten how wonderful Ernest Hemmingway's stories are and was very pleasantly surprised. I did not lay down the book until I finished it. It was pure entertainment, I have a few more of his books waiting to be read right now because of this one.
Great book, condition as noted and fast shipment.  Thanks
great condition, large print

column13: This book is amazing. Seriously worth checking out
column14: This book is amazing. Seriously worth checking out. Can easily be read in a day or two. Left such a lasting impression on me.

column13: The Sun Never Rises, not on this book.
column14: How does this book stink? Let me count the ways. It's a sophomoric ramble through drunkenness, fighting, impossible love(which is claimed, never developed), and abject hedonism. The writing style is sparse to the point of tedium. Sample? "We ate a French meal, it was a very good French meal." That's it, for all the descriptiveness in this book they could have been eating at Taco Bell. More? You are a glutton for punishment. "We drank absinthe, the absinthe was good." Get the picture? "That Cohn's awful. Yea, he's damned awful." This is grand literature? It transports you into another world? Not likely. The book is pretty much like this throughout. Drinking, brawls, pointless affairs, bullfighting, and no sense of the people as humans at all. It's the 20's version of the valley girl, total airheads. This is the most overrated piece of trash imaginable.

I just finished reading The Sun Also Rises by Hemingway. Overall, it was a short, enjoyable read. It took a little while for the story to take shape, but then the story came alive when the characters made their trip to Spain.

I am not as familiar with the WWI background, so I am not sure I picked up all the nuance of the story. In spite of that, the book is written in pretty clear prose. I interpreted this book as a story about friends struggling to make sense of the world. The book paints a little depressing picture of the time period and it gives you a perspective on post-war psyche. But, it also points to the difficulty people face in the absence of meaning and purpose. I am not sure there is any great moral or lesson from this story, it is more an attempt to place the reader in this setting and give the reader a different perspective.

column13: you need to be a bit of a Hemingway fan to truly enjoy this story
column14: Unlike Hemingway's For Whom the Bell Tolls and A Farewell to Arms, you need to be a bit of a Hemingway fan to truly enjoy this story. However, even the most novice Hemingway reader will certainly be captivated by the imagery Hemingway uses to bring this book to life.

I have one word to sum up this entire novel: Confusing. I had no idea how each line how to interpret everything, making the novel very hard to understand. I got some things, but most of the time I was so lost. Like the dad said in Big Fish, "All of the facts, none of the flavor". The only reason I bought this book was because I had to read in my school and luckily I got the cheapest copy. Anyway, don't waste your time. I've read other Hemingway novels and they were so much better. The Old Man and the Sea, For Whom the Bell Tolls, A Farewell to Arms, etc. and they all were WAY more understandable and easier to read than this. I still love Hemingway, but this novel lowered my faith in him. Total waste of time and energy.

This is the first Hemingway novel I read. It's a great story of living young in France and Spain and learning that in life there are cycles of good and bad, and that you must relish the good while the bad is still waiting to come around. The book itself held up better than most paperbacks and will still look good as long as you take care of it.

Which is saying something. The Great Gatsby is, in my opinion, a book without a false note. So is The Bridge of San Luis Rey. So is Faulkner's The Hamlet and Willa Cather's My Antonia There are not many others in American Fiction that I"m familiar with that never clang, which covers a wide field, of course and I only have read so much.
The Sun Also Rises is a wonderfully personal story and manages to leave out and exposit just the right amount to make sense and make the reader make sense. it would be interesting to have been in that young writer's mind to see how much he realized.
Sun is a wonderful read, like glass across a clear frozen lake, has all the depth you want it to have, all the clarity and all the emotion.
It is pretty dern amazing.
Have fun with your read.

column13: All for Sport. All for Pleasure.
column14:
Read it if … you’re a sucker for terse prose, Modernists, or feeling simultaneously superior and self-loathing about everything in general. Hemingway incorporates the confusion of the Lost Generation in a handful of iconic characters. TSAR is the perfect snapshot of the ruination The Great War and Modernism laid to young men and women and writers around the world.

Don’t read it if … your prosaic preferences lean toward more descriptive writing. Hemingway doesn’t tend to wow readers with flourishes or catchy turns of phrase, and, where other writers are more like painters, Hemingway is a blunt instrument hammering an image home. If the weather is wet, Hemingway will let you know things are wet and they’re damp and everything is wet and glistening with water because it’s raining wetness. If there are soldiers marching down a mountain, goddammit, Hemingway will force you to feel those footsteps in your bones. Don’t read Hemingway if you’re not prepared to be Hemingwayed.

This book is like … Giovanni’s Room by James Baldwin, which tells a slightly different tale of the expatriate scenes in Paris, only 30 odd years later. Like TSAR, Giovanni’s Room gives us protagonists who appear as cold observers, seemingly unfazed by the self-destruction all around them and yet complicit in it. And, of course, let’s not forget the most obvious allusions to The Story of Ferdinand by the master Munro Leaf, because, you know, bull fighting.

Check out my full review on LitBeetle.com: [...]

column13: The Sun Also Rises by Ernest Hemingway
column14: The only reason I gave this book 3 stars is that Hemingway's style was great. However, with much of Hemingway's stuff, the themes are often dark and the characters often depressed, confused or searching for something that the author never really lets them find. The week at the bullfighting town in Spain appeared to be a week of nearly non-stop drinking and sometimes squabbling for the characters. What stood as gripping for me was the author's description of the bullfights and the culture surrounding it. But alas, I never found a compelling hero to the story, nor did I find a moral to it, either. The end was quite anticlimax for me, leaving me wondering why I bothered.
A classic by one of the world's influential authors. Rarely will a person write such a work and embed it with its heart.

I read this again. Maybe my third time. I tried to see what the power in this novel is...again. As a classic from a Nobel winner, why shy away from really appreciating it?

Well, it's everything good that has been said about it.

Here's what I found that helped me toward loving ths book: Read it slowly at one sitting.

By doing this, you get into the rhythm of the prose, the rhythm of the characters' lives ,the traveling, the dialog. You feel part of the setting, the novel, the times. When I read this previously, I didn't \\" feel\\" connected to it. By reading it all at once, I felt the power of all the above and Hemingway's talent.
There is nothing to say about this book that had not been said yet. It is a classic, what else can I say?

I've long been a fan of Hemingway's clean, concise, and yet beautiful writing.  He tells a story in the simplest of terms, and yet manages to capture all the emotion and imagery that other writer's struggle to relate in more verbose and flowery measures.  It's always a pleasure to revisit Hemingway's works.
Classic Post-Modernism novel about individuals from " The Lost Generation". It's an interesting read and I would recommend it to others. Excellent delivery.

In my opinion, I'm glad that I read this book, although I'm not sure that I'd read it again. Full of travels and adventures, Paris, drinking,  fishing in Spain, drinking, week long bullfight festival in Pamplona, drinking. Probably quite scandalous when published in 1926. The main female character goes through several men. Ends with you wanting more and wondering what will happen next. Terrence Shellock, Ocean City, NJ

column13: The sun should set for this.
column14:
Been trying to read well known and classic lit and.authors. Wanted to read more
than just Old Man and the Sea ( which was awesome) so I picked this. What a waste! Will try one more of his
before I give up on him.

"You can't get away from yourself by moving from one place to another"

This is classic Hemingway and an important book to read if you are thinking about how to live.

As a high school student, I read this novel by accident over, over a lazy summer. It belonged to my sister, and I simply read the first page or two, just out of boredom. It completely changed my life and how I viewed literature.

What I love most about Hemingway is his narrative style. It's terse, direct, and concise. Instead of pages of exposition, he simply reports the actions of his characters, leaving judgment up to the reader. He reveals his characters subtly, and they evolve throughout the work. Each character feels real...they seem like real people with real motivations. Each is flawed, yet noble in their own way and for their own reasons.

Hemingway was the original thrill seeker, and his settings were always unique and colorful. The reason we all know of the "running of the bulls" in Pamplona is because of this novel. He documented his time, unique locales, and interesting people in each of his splendid works.

I wish this was required reading in all high schools. Though it was his first novel, I believe it was his very best. If you haven't read it in a while, you're overdue to read it again.

column13: Something about him clicks with me
column14: As I read him I just liked his books.  Great stories, have read most of his works and just gel with him.

This is a classic. Which depicts what it was like to be a part of what Gertrude Stein famously called 'the lost generation.' The men and women many of whom like Hemingway served in world war I and who stayed in Europe as expats. They made up much of the literati and artists of Paris. Many have reviewed this novel better than I ever could. But to me it is also a heartbreaking story about a love that can never be physically embraced. A work about what it really means to be a man, a writer an artist.

One of my favorite scenes is where the main character Jake Barns gives away his war medals to young women in a night club. That is a beautiful act. That shows Jake was a man of real courage, decency, humility, who understood that medals really have no meaning that too often they are the sticks that politicians and soulless Generals use to get teenage boys to fight and keep fighting. Jake knew they are a chimera.

column13: my last of the Hemingway books.... I did not like this book at all
column14:
a couple or more years ago, I decided to read all the Hemingway books.
this was my last, and it really is not that great. I was bored with the story, the
characters, everything. I somehow finished the book ... and put it in the free
bin at the grocery ..

what can ya say ...
A good story by Hemingway, easy to relate to for me. Not the book I was actually looking for though.

Had read this before and really liked it. Couldn't remember much of it except
something about bullfights and Jake's wonderful last line. (which I remembered as Lady Brett's.)
Have only read the 1st six chapters. Geez, they drank a lot and were not very happy people.
I really think maybe there is a connection between the characters of Mike and Brett with Zelda and F. Scott Fitzgerald.
Just a guess. Looking forward to the bullfighting part. Easy read. Really gives a good feel, I believe for that time in Paris for
those people.

Sadly I did not find this gem on my own, but nonetheless, it it simply an amazing book.
I would recommend it for everyone!
I couldn't find a way to connect with the main character and the story he was telling. The tale seemed repetitive and dull. Perhaps it was me but could not appreciate Hemingway's style in this novel.

I'll be honest, I was bored during the majority of the book. The characters were, for the most part, unsympathetic. The premise was dull, and, though it is, in theory, Jake talking about Cohn, I didn't feel like it was Cohn's story...and he was the only one with much of a background at all. I am not a fan of the style, the simplistic adjectives and the high amounts of repetition (possibly a carry over from Hemingway's own association with Stein),and I probably wouldn't read it again, but I am content that I read it at least once.

column13: A blur of romantic and alcoholic frustration.
column14:
Ever wonder why Hemingway, the literary darling of our childhood and youth, has dropped out of fashion? "The Sun Also Rises" (published 1926, to mixed reviews), his first major work, and often declared his best novel, provides an answer. In my view, stimulated by a recent reading, my first, one might search fruitlessly to find a flatter and more colorless array of disappointment.

To be fair, the novel is almost a century old, and was highly experimental and daring in its time, and will undoubtedly always occupy a slot in the history of American literature. Yet, one is hard-pressed to overlook the gratuitous anti-Semitism and the thinly veiled misogyny, blanketing the main characters' world view. Then we have the dearth of conventional literary appeal: excessive use of the verb to be, and the passive voice, a poverty of inventive or fresh simile or metaphor, tediously short dialogue and slang (now dated), a wearying and self-conscious affectation of both short and long sentences, together with an aimless, almost slovenly, structure.

Granted, Hemingway has nailed an immature and lost generation of drunks and wandering souls lost between the world wars, (proto-beats, and proto hippies) and enriched their thin atmosphere with free-wheeling European travel, picturesque mountain trout fishing, decaying European aristocracy, innocent peasantry, and blood-soaked bullfights, all leanly described, and some, more or less, employed as symbols.

But the relentless machismo wears thin, the 24 hour a day drinking quickly becomes annoying, and the days spent with rude American twenty-thirty somethings traipsing around the Spanish countryside, usually from bar to bar, and in a blur of romantic and alcoholic frustration, end with relief, at least for this reader.
No it did not meet my expectations it literally fell apart while reading it.  The binding was brittle.  Not satisfied

column13: This book is a hot mess
column14: This book is a hot mess in terms of writing, plot (there is none), content and characters who are a bunch of drunks who like bullfighting and consuming alcohol.

column13: Not the masterpiece it's cracked up to be, but pretty good nonetheless
column14:
When I go back and try to read some of my favourite novels from the 30s and 40s, like DH Lawrence and Under the Volcano by Malcolm Lowry, it’s a tough slog. The prose and imagery are as dense as a rainforest. In places I could use a machete to hack through the thickets of what now seems like purple prose.

Hemingway has never been my favourite author from that era, but I have to concede that his writing, because of the journalistic brevity and lack of fancy synonyms and run-on sentences, has made him more readable than the aforementioned authors. “The river looked nice. It was always pleasant crossing bridges in Paris.” That’s a typical example of Papa’s stripped-down style in this novel. And that is the essence of his originality and main contribution to literature.

It looks simple, but it’s not that simple to do. As Nathaniel Hawthorne noted, “Easy reading makes for damn hard writing.”

For a first novel, this tale of expatriates in France and Spain has its shortcomings: overly long conversations (mostly in bars), a lack of character development, and little sense of what the opening quote from Gertrude Stein, “You are all a lost generation,” adds up to in the book. None of them seem all that lost to me. Lost in their bottles. Lost to each other, perhaps. But not lost in these alien cultures, which is the usual expat’s dilemma.

Essentially a love story about the macho Jake, Hem’s stand-in character, and the beautiful British butterfly Brett Ashley, who flits from man to man, the narrative hits its stride when the characters arrive in Spain. Papa’s strongest points as a storyteller emerge when describing the running of the bulls in Pamplona, which continues to this day, along with the bullfights, and the chaotic, drunken revelry of the fiesta.

Jake, and by extension the author, reserves his real love not for Brett but for the bullfighters. “Belmonte, in his best days, worked always in the terrain of the bull. This way he gave the sensation of coming tragedy. People went to the corrida to see Belmonte, to be given tragic sensations, and perhaps to see the death of Belmonte.”

In the end, the multiple love stories implode and, because of the narrator’s reticence, not enough is felt. Still, it will be a long while before I get that image out of my head of what Brett does with the severed ear of the bull the matador gave her.

This is not one of Hem’s masterpieces, contrary to all the hype, but as a workbook for him to work out his signature style of punchy, still influential, minimalism, and his manly subject matter, it is, nonetheless, a seminal novel.

I read this years ago.  I appreciate Hemingway's writing so much more now that I've had some life experience.  It's so simple and easy to read.  Yet so rich with life.  Buy this book, you will read and re-read one of the American greats.

Ernest Hemmingway’s book “The Sun Also Rises” is a fabulous depiction of life during the aftermath of the First World War amongst the popular “Lost Generation”. Hemmingway himself was one of these in the “Lost Generation.”
After the war he suffered injuries that made him impotent which fueled his nomadic and detached lifestyle. After the war he wandered around Paris for several years where he came to write “The Sun Also Rises” in which he could be portrayed as a parallel to the protagonist Jake. In “The Sun Also Rises” Hemmingway gives the reader an inside look into life through the eyes of Jake, a young intelligent writer fresh out of World War I. Along with his group of friends of other intellectual writers and musicians, Jake travels throughout Europe to end up Spain for the famous Bull Run where the story comes to an conclusion. Through out this book Jake and most other male characters become intoxicated with Lady Brett Ashley until it is protracted to the extent of creepy devotion in some cases. Brett is a very confident, strong willed woman who seems to stumble from man to man, always with a drink in her hand. This group of friends or rather Brett’s old and thrown out company, simply wander around aimlessly, living vicariously through their depressions and anxieties from the war but never without their most important entity, liquor. They seem to be enjoying life as it comes to them without too much purpose, as the “lost Generation” does. However Brett always seems to return to Jake even though she is reluctant to be with him due to him impotence. It seems to me, as if this book is a compilation of the many men of Lady Brett Ashley and the life they lead after her.

Although the book does not seem to have a centralized plot, Hemmingway’s style of writing is adept and truly captures the readers mind and brings them onto the streets of Paris circa 1920’s. His writing is vivid and descriptive in nature and keeps the reader intrigued withholding just enough detail, leaving enough for the reader to imagine. All the while he is discrete enough in the events as to hint towards a drunken night that may or may not have led to sexual activities, letting the story really become our own imagination subconsciously. Hemmingway paints a beautiful picture but allows the reader to determine the colors. Which leads us, as the reader, to believe what we want to believe without even knowing that we planted in into our brains, in this way making the story ours. Which inflicts the reader with a deep connection to the book and to the author who so brilliantly wrote it. This makes me and probably many others enjoy Hemmingway’s numerous books. Although my Hemmingway literature is not quite up to par, certain characteristics have been noticeably constant, such as the descriptive, yet vagueness of his writing. Amongst this was the central theme of the persona of the true men from the “Lost Generation.” Hemmingway simply put it “Enjoying living was learning to get your money’s worth and knowing when you had it.” (152) The lifestyle that these fellows live was as Hemmingway put it, getting your moneys worth and the fact of knowing it. That is really all the “Lost Generation” was about learning when to get your money’s worth and living to the extent of learning this fact.
This is a quick and easy read, and is, in my opinion, one of Hemingway's best. Takes you back to early 1900s Paris, and it's as if you are there. Fantastic!

I liked A FAREWELL TO ARMS better, but this was a very enjoyable Hemingway book.  I didn't think so much of his sparse prose style but it really grew on me.  Some of the characters are downright hilarious and there's enough action with the bullfighting to hold a reader's interest.
Required reading, good book.  Would recommend everyone read this book.  It is a classic.  Good price and availability on Amazon.

Probably my favorite book by Hemingway, it was one of his earliest books. It is a book about bullfighting, but the conflict and companionship that arises between the characters makes it seem like more than that. An enjoyable read the whole way through.

I would recommend this product along with Sirens of Morning Light by Benjamin Anderson, a quest for a man in Iowa to regain his identity, which becomes entangled with people who claim to have known him when he discovers he is a scientific experiment. Make sure not to miss either book.

Ernest Hemingway created a cast of characters in The Sun Also Rises that embodied all characteristics and partook in activities associated with the Lost Generation. The characters drank heavily, partied constantly, and engaged in casual affairs, but only Jake Barnes, the protagonist of the novel, seemed to express any remorse for his past actions. The characters Hemingway created seemed two-dimensional, focusing more on simple pleasure than anything with any weight. Although the novel is praised as an American classic and Hemingway’s masterpiece, The Sun Also Rises features many simple characters that are not extremely likable and undergo little change through the novel. Many argue that the characters are simply masking pain that the World War One created, but Jake fought in the war and shows more depth than any other characters.
Jake Barnes described his friends as shallow in the novel himself and said that he had a “disgusted feeling” around them in Chapter 14. Jake stands as perhaps the only remotely realistic character; he shows sadness over his injury, feelings for Brett, and nostalgia for the time before World War One. Others, however, do not share the same realistic traits. Lady Brett Ashley hopped from lover to lover, Robert Cohn idolized beautiful woman, and Mike served as the bully of the novel. The characters never developed and remained flat throughout the progression of the novel.
Despite the popularity of Hemingway’s The Sun Also Rises, the characters were displayed simplistically. The cast of characters were not convincing, nor did they show any development over the course of the novel. As a result, Jake Barnes was the sole character in the novel that seemed even partially realistic and could invoke empathy from readers.
Got this book as an early Christmas gift and just finished it!  Great book to read. Hemingway's words puts you right into the country side and cafe's in Spain.

Ernest Hemingway is without a doubt one of the great writers. When I was reading the book, I was transported to the time and place that the characters occupied via the dialog, setting and descriptive narrative, which was a post-World War I generation in Paris. It is a story about people (Jake and Brett) vs. plot.

column13: Too Harsh a Reality for My Taste
column14:
My first experience with Hemingway and it was not particularly an easy one. First, the writing style was harsh and crass especially for someone like me, who's particularly fond of Victorian literature. Second, it's hard to accept the characters' many undesirable traits. What went so wrong in each character's life to make them wind up that way? It was effective in expressing Hemingway's intention but there was too much description of the activities which I normally consider subject matters of interest to men, particularly fishing and bullfighting. The story was interesting enough however that I flew through the book to find out, what next? At the end, there was a feeling that things would never improve and that they would all probably die too young and in some tragic circumstance with a variety of venereal diseases or in need of liver transplants from excessive alcohol consumption.

The Spain portion of it was interesting and whet my appetite for travel to that country and reminded me about the excitement of travel in Europe in general. In spite of the negative feelings, I intend to read his other major works.
Never really read Hemingway before I had to read this book for ENG332 American Lit II. This is now my favorite novel.
they get on a train to spain and you're just like "i don't really want to hang out with these people anymore."

column13: Plot as hard to find as Hemingway's adjectives
column14:
After hearing about Hemingway all my life, and having read THE OLD MAN AND THE SEA as a teenager and still having a lingering memory of it, I looked forward to plunging in to finally experience Hemingway firsthand as an adult. I can't say after reading SUN ALSO RISES that I came away rueful of what I've been missing all my life.

I appreciate the people who love this book. I'll grant it moves them. I understand why it is a milestone in
Twentieth Century literature, with the emergence of Hemingway's power-lifting of the language and his famous, \\"clean, well-lighted page.\\" I acknowledge its deserved place in literary history.

But it just didn't grab me. Ennui and wasted lives--and prodigious amounts of alcohol--didn't hold my attention after awhile. The characters' liberal use of the \\"n\\" word (Amazon won't let me write it out) when they discuss a black prize fighter was jolting, but can perhaps be forgiven as a throwback to the times. The insensate cruelty to animals was horrifying, but might be read metaphorically as symbolic of the characters' own wounds and their emotional goring of each other. The anti-Semitism that runs through the novel, in terms of how the characters view Cohn, is hard to take in any time period and hard to excuse. Okay, maybe that too is a reflection of the characters' times, especially considering what was coming in Europe. But add the endless boozing, the occasional brawling, and the bloodied bulls, as well as the copious dialogue that leaves so much for the reader to fill in to try to figure out what's going on with these aimless people and their seemingly trivial lives, and The Souffle Never Rises for me.

If you think this novel is great, I won't argue. I just kept waiting for something to happen, for something definitive to occur, for some resolution of something, no matter how small. Maybe that is the whole point. For these characters of the Lost Generation, there is no answer.

Probably the reason this tepid novel lives on is Hemingway's revolutionary use of language, which I'll grant is formidable, if not always gratifying. Sometimes it just seems grating, like a rattling engine that needs oil. I'll remember the language, if not the story. The plot? A group of useless, overindulged people get bored drinking in Paris, so they go to Spain to drink while looking at bullfights, and then they go home (undoubtedly to drink some more). That's pretty much it. Can't someone find these tedious characters a job?

This book is exactly the one my daughter's teachers/school required.  I am impressed with the service because the book arrived within days.  And the best part is that it was less expensive than if I had bought it through the school's bookseller.  I will never buy another schoolbook from the school's bookseller without looking in Amazon first.

I read this after hearing so much from my friends....sad to say I didn't like it. I do like the classics but this one didn't hit home with me. I felt like it was just a bunch of men fighting over a girl they all loved but couldn't get.
I like this book, especially since we were in Pamplona, Spain last year and walked the same streets Hemingway walked.

I purchased this as a replacement copy, a druggie stole my other copy. With that, I've been happy with Hemingway and his writing so I was happy to read this again and add it to my collection of Hemingway.

Nothing new to add here.  I just wanted to add my 5 star rating to this book.  I'm reading it for the third time.  I've always liked the book; each time I see something new.  I'm always hit by Jake's explanation of the role steers play in calming (and giving a target for aggression) the bulls.  Jake of course, lost his balls in the war.

column13: They went to the bar and drank. And drank. And drank.
column14:
This \\"classic\\" is a huge disappointment, and I don't see why this was the book that catapulted Hemingway into a pantheon of great writers.

Almost none of the elements of what constitute good fiction are in this book, such as any emotional or psychological growth among the characters. The main character, Jake, is really Hemingway, and this novel is a barely disguised diary of his time in Europe wasting time in cafes and bars with his friends, talking about their inability to write (hint: maybe it's because they were always drunk?) and in particular, his famous travels to Spain to watch and write about the bull-fights that mesmerized him. It is also about the love and lust several of the characters, including Jake, have for Lady Brette Ashley, a not-quite-divorced, penniless, beautiful and reckless woman who continually runs off with men she has just met, notwithstanding her engagement to Mike. She is supposed to be a sympathetic character, but her total lack of judgment, total lack of consideration for the feelings of others, and inability to pull her life together, don't earn sympathy in my book.

In fact, the only character who I found even slightly sympathetic is Robert Cohn, a Jewish friend who became a boxer in part \\"to counteract the feeling of inferiority and shyness he had felt on being treated as a Jew at Princeton.\\" Part of my disappointment in this book is that Hemingway opens the story writing absorbingly about Cohn, but then he lets Cohn disappear from the narrative for a very long time, leaving the reader to wonder what role he will play later in the story. Cohn also loves Brette (who doesn't?) and while his judgement in women is just as bad in this regard as all the rest of the men who fall for her, I felt his pain at having been able to run away with her for a week or so and then, as all her other lovers, get unceremoniously dumped for a newer face. Also, he knows he is disliked in this sophisticated crowd for being a Jew, and behind his back is called a slew of anti-Semitic names.

Having just read The Paris Wife, a pretty good historical novel about Hemingway's first wife, Hadley, I also knew that The Sun Also Rises makes no mention of Hadley as a character, though they were married at the time of these experiences and she was with him in these travels. Though he dedicates the book to her, Hadley must have been enormously hurt to have been written out of this narrative, which Hemingway finalized with the help of one of his many drinking buddies, F. Scott Fitzgerald.

Giving credit where credit is due, Hemingway's spare style of writing, often the subject of parody, can be arresting, but the repetition of the most mundane details is tiresome, as is much of the narrative:

\\"I feel sorry about Cohn,\\" Bill said. \\"He had an awful time.\\"

\\"Oh, to hell with Cohn,\\" I said.

\\"Where do you suppose he went?\\"

\\"Up to Paris.\\"

\\"What do you suppose he'll do?

\\"Oh, to hell with him.\\"

Jake is almost alarmingly empty as a character; he is seemingly moved only by the artistry of the gifted matador and his love for the unattainable, impossible Brette, but his voice, Hemingway's voice, is stilted, spare and ultimately unsympathetic.

The title of the book comes straight from Ecclesiastes, from which Hemingway quotes when the book opens, but the characters in the book usually miss the sunrise because they are sleeping off their mindless drunkenness from the night before. Maybe this \\"Lost Generation\\" wouldn't have been quite so lost if they had all met at an AA meeting instead and made something of their lives.ind his back is called a slew of anti-Semitic names.

Having just read The Paris Wife, a pretty good historical novel about Hemingway's first wife, Hadley, I also knew that The Sun Also Rises makes no mention of Hadley as a character, though they were married at the time of these experiences and she was with him in these travels. Though he dedicates the book to her, Hadley must have been enormously hurt to have been written out of this narrative, which Hemingway finalized with the help of one of his many drinking buddies, F. Scott Fitzgerald.

Giving credit where credit is due, Hemingway's spare style of writing, often the subject of parody, can be arresting, but the repetition of the most mundane details is tiresome, as is much of the narrative:

\\"I feel sorry about Cohn,\\" Bill said. \\"He had an awful time.\\"

\\"Oh, to hell with Cohn,\\" I said.

\\"Where do you suppose he went?\\"

\\"Up to Paris.\\"

\\"What do you suppose he'll do?

\\"Oh, to hell with him.\\"

Jake is almost alarmingly empty as a character; he is seemingly moved only by the artistry of the gifted matador and his love for the unattainable, impossible Brette, but his voice, Hemingway's voice, is stilted, spare and ultimately unsympathetic.

The title of the book comes straight from Ecclesiastes, from which Hemingway quotes when the book opens, but the characters in the book usually miss the sunrise because they are sleeping off their mindless drunkenness from the night before. Maybe this \\"Lost Generation\\" wouldn't have been quite so lost if they had all met at an AA meeting instead and made something of their lives.

If I had a \\"Whaa??\\" shelf, this would be the first book on it. This \\"masterpiece\\" is about some WWI vets who drink a lot, ride a train, and see a bullfight. The end. I like opaque books, but I could find more symbolism on a Chinese food menu than in this book. (Does the beef make a good father figure in number 26, the \\"Happy Family\\"? And how could he, when number 25 is shrimp fried rice?)

column14:
