column13: Made me want to read everything that Hemmingway has written.
column14: He has a great command of story.  Easy to fall into his world of fiction and wonderful characters.  Must read!

column13: Plot - 3, Characters - 3, Theme - 3, Voice - 3, Setting - 4, Overall - 3
column14:
1) Plot (3 stars) - In 1920's Europe, a group of American ex-pats who are bored with Paris decide to go watch the bullfights in Spain, a trip which tears them apart. It's a fine plot, but I felt much of it was devoted to sitting around some café or bar or hotel drinking and having the same conversations, not really getting anywhere or solving anything. Maybe that was the point, but it didn't make for a very engaging plot.

2) Characters (3 stars) - Jake is the tired, observant narrator, watching the restlessness and boredom of American ex-pats. Brett is the beautiful woman he and all the other boys fight over. The characters were nice in that they were rough and real (despite the stilted 1920s expressions), but I didn't find them especially different or interesting.

3) Theme (3 stars) - Unfortunately, the only moral I could pull out of this was a negative one--that without individual purpose, or a family to be part of, life is pretty sad and meaningless. And booze doesn't help either.

4) Voice (3 stars) - Hemingway has an easy to read style, but I must admit I was a little disappointed. He is lauded for his economy of language, but there seemed to be lots of places where there were unnecessary details or repeated thoughts.

5) Setting (4 stars) - Paris and Spain in the 1920s. The cafes, the hotels, the bullfights. I definitely felt like I was in another time and place. But I wasn't completely transported there because the details were sparse.

6) Overall (3 stars) - I finished it, but I don't think I'd recommend it. Maybe it was revolutionary in its day, but for me it felt a bit empty.

I enjoyed the background information about fighting bulls and about the Corida de Toros. Hemingway's narrative on the fiesta atmosphere put me in the mood for wanting to visit Spain and Pamplona.

I did not care about all the drinking. While I know that some persons handle the liquor better than others I can't imagine having too much fun with a hangover.
THIS BOOK WAS IN GREAT CONDITION AND WAS JUST WHAT I NEEDED TO COMPLETE MY SUMMER READING REQUIREMENTS, AND AT A GREAT PRICE.

Wrote this review for the Livermore Public Library 2013 Summer Reading Program:

Robert Cohn is a sober, former College Boxing Champion supposedly working on a writing career in Paris. Robert Cohn is the only sober character in The Sun Also Rises, alcohol flows freely and the characters seem to eat it for sustenance whether they're drinking Martinis in Paris, or Rioja for the Running of the Bulls in Pomplona.

What Robert Cohn has in common with his friend Jake Barnes is his affection for a Lady. The genuinely titled Lady Ashley has taken up with a very bankrupt lush named Michael, who hates Robert, loves Jake and is the fourth in this complex relationship between these four people.

Hemingway's economy of words is on full display in this novel, and I could not imagine trying to speed read this book, as every word counts. Part of the problem with The Sun Also Rises is that it is written for a contemporary readership, so Hemingway takes for granted that much of how life is lived in 1926 is common knowledge.

It is the responsibility of the reader to understand some of the things he mentioned. Fortunately, these items are few. I would recommend watching a good movie that features a similar setting and dialogue before diving into this novel. It is short enough to read twice in a week, so one may grasp its finer points, and to, perhaps, do a little research on the period

column13: It's not my cup of tea
column14: Sorry reading this along with my high school granddaughter  who is in advanced English. I' m sorry I just have not enjoyed reading this book. To much drinking

I have read this novel twice and, in all honesty, I did not enjoy it all that much either time. After reading it the second time I decided to read some criticism on the work to see what I was missing. I found two helpful collections of critical essays: [[ASIN:1555460453 The Sun Also Rises]] edited by Harold Bloom and [[ASIN:0737701951 The Sun Also Rises]] edited by Kelly Wand, and a short, book-length treatment of the novel: [[ASIN:0805779620 The Sun Also Rises: A Novel of the Twenties]] by Michael S. Reynolds. I would recommend all three to anyone wanting to dive a bit deeper into Hemingway's novel. I have also spent a great deal of time thinking and reflecting on the novel. I have been trying to figure out what I liked about the novel and why I did not like it more than I did. I have reached some tentative conclusions. I will try to share some of those conclusions in my review. I definitely think this novel is worth reading even if you do not enjoy it.

SUMMARY OF THE BOOK AND SOME OF THE THEMES

The novel follows a group of American and British expatriates in Paris. Jake is the war wounded narrator, Brett is the woman that pretty much all the men are in love with, Mike is Brett's fiance, Robert Cohn is the Jewish boxer who tends to be the punching bag of the group, and Bill is an American writer. Jake takes a trip every year to the San Fermin festival in Pamplona to see the bullfights and he invites the rest of the gang to go along. The novel is really about the changing relationships between the characters. Anyone expecting a really dramatic story is going to be disappointed. Traditionally the novel has been viewed as a portrait of the so-called \\"lost generation\\". Virtually all the characters in the novel, with the possible exception of Cohn, have been wounded in some way by the war, and there is no doubt that the characters in the novel are all suffering from a lack of sustaining values. However, Hemingway himself, apparently, did not like the term \\"lost generation\\" even though he used Gertrude Stein's quote as one of the epigraphs for the book.

There are really two central conflicts in the novel. The first is obvious and revolves around Robert Cohn's love for Brett. Robert Cohn is the only character who did not fight in the war and he is the only character who still believes wholeheartedly in Romantic love. He is the least cynical character in the book. He is, perhaps, a bit of a Don Quixote figure, still defending an outmoded value system. This gets him into trouble with Brett with whom he has a short affair. The relationship between Cohn and Brett highlights the dangers inherent in all relationships. If the two parties have different ideas about what the relationship is about, and different value systems in general, there is likely to be miscommunication, misunderstanding, and heart-break.

Cohn's conflict is the obvious conflict but, as Michael S. Reynolds points out in his book, the central conflict really revolves around Jake. It is difficult for the reader to pick up on the central conflict (I missed its importance until I read Reynolds' book) because Jake tends to make himself invisible in his narration. Jake is also in love with Brett but because of an unfortunate war wound is incapable of physical love. Brett seems to love Jake as well but cannot settle for a non-physical relationship so Jake has to watch her sleep around with other men. Jake has a real love for bullfighting. He goes to the bullfights every year and he is the only American that the Spanish respect as possessing aficion, or passion, about the bullfights. Bullfighting gives Jake some sustaining values: courage, honor and artistry, among them. However, Jake is unable to say no to Brett, and winds up pimping her out (Cohn's words) to the bullfighter Pedro Romero. A Spanish hotel owner with whom Jake has had a relationship for a number of years sees this and by the end of the novel the two are no longer on speaking terms. This is, as Reynolds argues, the central tragedy of the book. Jake was given a moral test and he failed, and his trips to Pamplona, if he continues them, will never be the same.

There are lots of interesting themes in the novel. There is, of course, the theme of emasculation. Jake is emasculated in the war and is further emasculated in his relationship to Brett. Despite Hemingway's reservations about the term \\"lost generation\\" the destruction of traditional values after the war is clearly another theme of the novel. Jake and his group do not really have a sustaining philosophy of life. At one point Jake claims that \\"Enjoying living was learning to get your money's worth\\" but claims that in five years that philosophy will \\"seem just as silly as all the other fine philosophies I've had\\" (148). Jake also claims \\"I did not care what it was all about. All I wanted to know was how to live in it\\" (148). Technically Jake is Catholic but we learn throughout the book that he does not have much religious feeling. That is, perhaps, another casualty of the war. So, throughout the novel, we see a group of people trying to figure out how to live, and not doing all that great a job at it.

Another theme that I found very interesting is the return to more primitive, one might say pagan, value systems as a replacement for Christianity. This shows up in a number of places in the book. Jake and Bill go on a fishing trip in Burguete and meet a British man named Harris and they all go to visit a monastery. They all agree it is a remarkable place but, Bill asks, \\"It isn't the same as fishing though, is it?\\" The others agree that it is not. Clearly, there is an attempt to return to nature here, and nature is viewed as more reinvigorating than traditional religion. The only time the reader gets any sense of health reading this novel is in the descriptions of nature and in the characters' contact with nature. There is also an interesting mix between the Christian and the pagan in the San Fermin festival. It is, in name at least, a Christian festival in honor of a Christian saint, but the practice of bullfighting (sacrificing the bull) is a much more primitive religious practice, and it is clear that all of the characters, especially Jake, are much more moved by the bullfighting than they are by the Christian aspects of the festival. There is, it seems to me, an attempt in the novel to move back to a more primitive form of religion to find some sustaining values after the collapse of Christianity. There is a similarity here between Hemingway's novel and T.S. Eliot's poem [[ASIN:0393974995 The Waste Land (Norton Critical Editions)]].

WHAT I LIKED ABOUT THE BOOK OR WHAT HEMINGWAY DID WELL

Now, before I try to explain what I did not like about the novel I want to highlight a few things I liked about the novel. First, Hemingway does a great job portraying powerful emotions. There is an interesting exchange between William Faulkner and Ernest Hemingway that I think is relevant. William Faulkner criticized Hemingway by saying \\"He has never been known to use a word that might send a reader to the dictionary\\". Hemingway replied by saying \\"Poor Faulkner. Does he really think big emotions come from big words?\\" Personally, I much prefer Faulkner to Hemingway, but Hemingway definitely has a point here. Sometimes simple and direct is more powerful. There is a scene where Mike and Robert Cohn get into a fight. Mike calls Robert Cohn a steer because he is always \\"hanging about so\\". Hemingway (or Jake) simply writes \\"We were embarrassed\\". That is all that is necessary to convey the discomfort and the powerful emotions broiling beneath the surface of the scene. It is a very painful scene to read.

There is another scene where Brett says \\"Oh darling...I'm so miserable\\" and Jake replies \\"You were happy a minute ago\\" and Brett replies again \\"It's all gone\\". To me, that is much more powerful than if Brett hadtried to write an impromptu poem expressing her misery or provide some literary metaphor for her depression (\\"it is as wide and deep as the ocean\\" or something like that). Just saying \\"I'm so miserable\\" is more powerful than any literary trope which will tend to sound contrived. There is really an emotional hell just beneath all the quiet stoicism and ironic detachment of this novel and Hemingway does a great job conveying that in very few words. It is part of the reason reading the novel is not always all that pleasant of an experience. We can feel the misery and despair that is just beneath all the supposed gaiety. Hemingway also used to say that writers should portray how people actually feel rather than how they think they are supposed to feel. He definitely lives up to that. We have, I think, a lot of misconceptions about love. Love is a very complex emotion that is mixed up with a lot of other emotions and not all of them are positive. Pride and jealousy, for example, both play a huge role in the emotion we call love. Hemingway portrays the complexity of love, and the destructive ingredients of love, quite well.

Another thing I appreciated about the novel was Hemingway's sparse style in his descriptions of nature. I have been reading Henry David Thoreau recently, and as much as I love Thoreau, and as great a naturalist as he was, Thoreau still gets caught up in some of the standard literary tropes when describing nature. It does not feel direct. It is mediated by literature. Hemingway describes nature directly. There is actually a place in the book where he writes \\"The trees were green\\" (94) and that is his entire description of the trees. There are no descriptions of Apollo driving his winged chariot across the sky, etc.. Hemingway cuts all that away. If I am honest with myself I really prefer a slightly more ornate style. I prefer Faulkner to Hemingway. However, I do think that Hemingway's sparse style was necessary. It was like a cleansing forest fire. It removed a bunch of sick and dead foliage and allowed new shoots to bloom in literature. For that I am very grateful to Hemingway.

REASONS I DID NOT LIKE THE BOOK MORE THAN I DID

The first thing to be said is: I am a philosophy student. I love ideas and I enjoy metaphysical speculation. Hemingway was not really a philosopher. He was clearly more interested in character and emotion. There is big emotion in this book but there are not really any big ideas in it (none that I have found anyways). I have a feeling that Hemingway would have considered metaphysical speculation unhealthy. While I can appreciate that standpoint to life it does not change the fact that I tend to prefer novels that have big ideas in them or helpful insights into life. There are not that many helpful insights into life in the novel. There is not a lot of wisdom to be found. The characters are all lost, trying to figure out how to live in the world, and while they are certain that the old ways of living in the world are no longer possible, they do not yet have much to offer in their place. The lack of big ideas and insights into life is one reason I did not like the novel more than I did.

There is also a lack of sincerity in the novel. A number of critics really loved the fishing scene with Jake and Bill. They seemed to think it highlighted Bill's humor. To me, it highlighted Bill's incessant sarcasm and lack of sincerity. When they eat lunch they have kind of a mock saying of grace. I find this inability to be sincere to be a rather annoying trait. The characters are all very cynical and they clearly despise (at least at times) the one character who does not entirely share in their cynicism: Robert Cohn. To me, Robert Cohn and Brett Ashley were the most sympathetic characters in the book. Robert Cohn may be delusional but at least he believes in something and is willing to look foolish in defending what he believes. Brett Ashley may make emotional mincemeat out of most of the men in her life but she does not seem cruel to me. She is just wounded and desperate. From the criticism I read on the novel, however, it does not seem like most readers share my views. Most readers think that Cohn and Brett are very unsympathetic characters. If that is how Hemingway intended them it goes a long way towards explaining why I did not like the book more than I did. I think novelists should always try to understand their characters and genuine understanding always breeds sympathy. If a character is portrayed as extremely unsympathetic chances are they are a cardboard cutout character, with no real depth, enlightened by a merely superficial gaze.

The novel is also quite depressing. It is, in my opinion, much more depressing than more openly nihilistic novels (Celine and Beckett, for example). The characters are all caught up in what the philosopher Soren Kierkegaard called the aesthetic existential sphere. There is despair beneath the surface of the aesthetic sphere but it is unconscious. Openly nihilistic novels are expressions of conscious despair. In [[ASIN:0691020280 The Sickness Unto Death]] Kierkegaard argues that unconscious despair is worse than conscious despair. At least the person who experiences conscious despair is aware that they are sick and searching for a cure. The characters in this novel are attempting to drown their despair in alcohol and sex rather than facing it directly. It gives the novel a very unhealthy feeling that made it difficult for me to read at times. Perhaps that is what Hemingway intended. If so, he definitely succeeded. It is definitely powerful. Still, it reduced my enjoyment of the novel somewhat. The despair in the novel is slightly contagious and I found myself getting sucked into it at times.

One final observation and then I will bring this overly long review to a close. Part of my problem with the novel may be my own fault. It is possible I am reading the novel as if it were a nineteenth-century novel. I assume that Hemingway is trying to say something, that he wants the reader to adopt a particular position in relation to his characters, and that might not be the case. I may be assuming too much about the judgments that I think Hemingway wants me to make about his characters, and I tend to disagree with the judgments I think Hemingway wants me to make. For example, I assume that Hemingway approves of Jake's stoicism and disapproves of Cohn's lack of stoicism. Jake suffers silently while Cohn's primary sin seems to be that he is unwilling to suffer silently, to suck it up, so to speak. I do not agree with the values behind that judgment, so if that is the judgment that Hemingway wants the reader to make, it is another reason I did not enjoy the novel more than I did. However, it is possible that Hemingway is not expecting any particular judgments from the reader. Modern novels do not tell the reader what to think in the same way that older novels do. The reader is allowed to make up their own mind. Things happen, and those events effect different characters in particular ways, but there is no God's eye view from which to decide which reactions are \\"good\\" and which are \\"bad\\". So, if I could convince myself that Hemingway is simply holding a mirror up to a particular time and place, and leaving it up to the reader to form their own judgments, I would, I think, enjoy the novel much more than I did.tried to write an impromptu poem expressing her misery or provide some literary metaphor for her depression (\\"it is as wide and deep as the ocean\\" or something like that). Just saying \\"I'm so miserable\\" is more powerful than any literary trope which will tend to sound contrived. There is really an emotional hell just beneath all the quiet stoicism and ironic detachment of this novel and Hemingway does a great job conveying that in very few words. It is part of the reason reading the novel is not always all that pleasant of an experience. We can feel the misery and despair that is just beneath all the supposed gaiety. Hemingway also used to say that writers should portray how people actually feel rather than how they think they are supposed to feel. He definitely lives up to that. We have, I think, a lot of misconceptions about love. Love is a very complex emotion that is mixed up with a lot of other emotions and not all of them are positive. Pride and jealousy, for example, both play a huge role in the emotion we call love. Hemingway portrays the complexity of love, and the destructive ingredients of love, quite well.

Another thing I appreciated about the novel was Hemingway's sparse style in his descriptions of nature. I have been reading Henry David Thoreau recently, and as much as I love Thoreau, and as great a naturalist as he was, Thoreau still gets caught up in some of the standard literary tropes when describing nature. It does not feel direct. It is mediated by literature. Hemingway describes nature directly. There is actually a place in the book where he writes \\"The trees were green\\" (94) and that is his entire description of the trees. There are no descriptions of Apollo driving his winged chariot across the sky, etc.. Hemingway cuts all that away. If I am honest with myself I really prefer a slightly more ornate style. I prefer Faulkner to Hemingway. However, I do think that Hemingway's sparse style was necessary. It was like a cleansing forest fire. It removed a bunch of sick and dead foliage and allowed new shoots to bloom in literature. For that I am very grateful to Hemingway.

REASONS I DID NOT LIKE THE BOOK MORE THAN I DID

The first thing to be said is: I am a philosophy student. I love ideas and I enjoy metaphysical speculation. Hemingway was not really a philosopher. He was clearly more interested in character and emotion. There is big emotion in this book but there are not really any big ideas in it (none that I have found anyways). I have a feeling that Hemingway would have considered metaphysical speculation unhealthy. While I can appreciate that standpoint to life it does not change the fact that I tend to prefer novels that have big ideas in them or helpful insights into life. There are not that many helpful insights into life in the novel. There is not a lot of wisdom to be found. The characters are all lost, trying to figure out how to live in the world, and while they are certain that the old ways of living in the world are no longer possible, they do not yet have much to offer in their place. The lack of big ideas and insights into life is one reason I did not like the novel more than I did.

There is also a lack of sincerity in the novel. A number of critics really loved the fishing scene with Jake and Bill. They seemed to think it highlighted Bill's humor. To me, it highlighted Bill's incessant sarcasm and lack of sincerity. When they eat lunch they have kind of a mock saying of grace. I find this inability to be sincere to be a rather annoying trait. The characters are all very cynical and they clearly despise (at least at times) the one character who does not entirely share in their cynicism: Robert Cohn. To me, Robert Cohn and Brett Ashley were the most sympathetic characters in the book. Robert Cohn may be delusional but at least he believes in something and is willing to look foolish in defending what he believes. Brett Ashley may make emotional mincemeat out of most of the men in her life but she does not seem cruel to me. She is just wounded and desperate. From the criticism I read on the novel, however, it does not seem like most readers share my views. Most readers think that Cohn and Brett are very unsympathetic characters. If that is how Hemingway intended them it goes a long way towards explaining why I did not like the book more than I did. I think novelists should always try to understand their characters and genuine understanding always breeds sympathy. If a character is portrayed as extremely unsympathetic chances are they are a cardboard cutout character, with no real depth, enlightened by a merely superficial gaze.

The novel is also quite depressing. It is, in my opinion, much more depressing than more openly nihilistic novels (Celine and Beckett, for example). The characters are all caught up in what the philosopher Soren Kierkegaard called the aesthetic existential sphere. There is despair beneath the surface of the aesthetic sphere but it is unconscious. Openly nihilistic novels are expressions of conscious despair. In [[ASIN:0691020280 The Sickness Unto Death]] Kierkegaard argues that unconscious despair is worse than conscious despair. At least the person who experiences conscious despair is aware that they are sick and searching for a cure. The characters in this novel are attempting to drown their despair in alcohol and sex rather than facing it directly. It gives the novel a very unhealthy feeling that made it difficult for me to read at times. Perhaps that is what Hemingway intended. If so, he definitely succeeded. It is definitely powerful. Still, it reduced my enjoyment of the novel somewhat. The despair in the novel is slightly contagious and I found myself getting sucked into it at times.

One final observation and then I will bring this overly long review to a close. Part of my problem with the novel may be my own fault. It is possible I am reading the novel as ifit were a nineteenth-century novel. I assume that Hemingway is trying to say something, that he wants the reader to adopt a particular position in relation to his characters, and that might not be the case. I may be assuming too much about the judgments that I think Hemingway wants me to make about his characters, and I tend to disagree with the judgments I think Hemingway wants me to make. For example, I assume that Hemingway approves of Jake's stoicism and disapproves of Cohn's lack of stoicism. Jake suffers silently while Cohn's primary sin seems to be that he is unwilling to suffer silently, to suck it up, so to speak. I do not agree with the values behind that judgment, so if that is the judgment that Hemingway wants the reader to make, it is another reason I did not enjoy the novel more than I did. However, it is possible that Hemingway is not expecting any particular judgments from the reader. Modern novels do not tell the reader what to think in the same way that older novels do. The reader is allowed to make up their own mind. Things happen, and those events effect different characters in particular ways, but there is no God's eye view from which to decide which reactions are \\"good\\" and which are \\"bad\\". So, if I could convince myself that Hemingway is simply holding a mirror up to a particular time and place, and leaving it up to the reader to form their own judgments, I would, I think, enjoy the novel much more than I did.

What is The Sun Also Rises about? Hmm, that's hard to say. This story doesn't really seem to be about anything. The true meaning must be taken more from symbols and allusion rather than the direct actions of the characters.

The story follows a group of bored socialites as they travel from Paris to Pamplona, Spain in post World War I Europe, no doubt in search of some kind of meaning for their morally bankrupt lives. The group spends several days in Pamplona watching the running of the bulls and the bull fights, before splitting up and going back to their respective homes.

Ernest Hemingway is considered by many to be one of America's most brilliant writers, winning both the Nobel Prize for Literature, and the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction. A brilliant writer, but ultimately unhappy it seems. He was married four times and eventually took his own life in 1961. The Sun Also Rises was Hemingway's first novel, written in 1924 and published in 1926.

William Hurt became one of my favorite audio book narrators after hearing only one of his books, Stephen King's Hearts in Atlantis. He has a really unusual style that, at first, sounds odd and bewildering. After listening to him for a while, however, he really grew on me. Frankly, I don't think I would have picked up this audiobook if he hadn't been the narrator. I enjoyed his reading again, although I can't honestly pinpoint what it is I like about him.

The Sun Also Rises was a tough one for me. On the surface, it seems to be a story about wealthy people who lead empty and meaningless lives. In part, I think that's what Ernest Hemingway intended, but why are their lives so empty? I did a bit of reading up on this novel, looking at what other people had to say about it. They throw around words like \\"expatriate\\" and \\"disillusioned\\" and \\"lost generation.\\" Why this so-called \\"lost generation\\" became so \\"disillusioned\\" that they \\"expatriated\\" themselves is beyond me. Were they disillusioned with humanity because of the war, or was it just America's involvement in the war? I guess I'll have to leave that up to the scholars. Even though I didn't really get this audiobook, I learned a lot about the running of the bulls in Pamplona, and also about a little slice of American history as well.ey disillusioned with humanity because of the war, or was it just America's involvement in the war? I guess I'll have to leave that up to the scholars. Even though I didn't really get this audiobook, I learned a lot about the running of the bulls in Pamplona, and also about a little slice of American history as well.

You can't read this novel with its elegant characters living the high life without reflecting how much Ernest  Hemingway himself shared the same wild, glamorous but ultimately empty lifestyle.  It makes his sparse writing with its powerful evocation of the glamorous, ambitious group of 30 somethings enjoying the best parties and adrenalin rushes of interwar Europe all the more poignant.  The second half of the book is the most absorbing because it is here that Hemingway writes of the things he really loves - peasant life in Spain and bullfighting.  What would he have imagined happening to Brett, Jake and the unfortunate Robert Cohn in the political maelstrom that swept through Europe within a decade? How in their 40s would they have reacted to the rise of fascism and eventually world war?  The fickle Lady Ashley one has no hope of redemption for in a hypothetical sequel, but Jake would surely have \\"done the right thing\\" in defence of freedom and Cohn too, given a chance to act with honour and courage for a larger cause?

column13: Glad I revisisted this Master of prose
column14: Like most of us, I had Hemmingway forced on my in high school. Old Man and the Sea was the penance paid for some grievance I and the rest of my classmates must have committed. It didn't have sex, hot rods or music. I didn't care for it much. So anyway, years later for whatever reason I decided to give Papa another try. So I picked up \\"The Sun Also Rises\\".  What a pleasant and wonderful book. The prose overall is masculine. Hemmingway doesn't bother with feelings, hues or ornamentals.  He tackles the story straight-forward with no frills. The writing style I found to be quite refreshing. Here was a man's man talking like a man. The story itself plodded but set the tone for the trip to Spain where the book picks up the pace. Through the story, I could start to pick up on the subtle of things Hemmingway was writing but not saying outright. It was very human and through the facade of masculinity, very touching. I absolutely loved the book. Now I know why my teachers forced Old Man and the Sea on me all those years ago.

Profound, stirring, insightful, mysteriously moving...nah.  I have this terrible habit of finishing every book I read, even the ones I hate.  This is the most tedious thing I've ever read.  Couldn't wait for it to be over.  Near the end my eyes skimmed past entire paragraphs because I knew it would just lead to more of Jake and Company ordering drinks, talking in half sentences about nothing, taking a bath before dinner, or sitting in a cafe or restaurant with more talk about...nothing.  Hemingway is a great author.  But this heap of nonsense?  Nope.  And yes, for all the literary snobs out there, I 'get' what the novel was trying to say, so dial down the indignant hissy fits.  It's just that Papa could have said it more succinctly.  Unfortunately, his final statement with the shotgun did say it succinctly.

column13: Book in good shape, story not.
column14: I had a really tough time with the character portrayal.  Characters seemed unrealistic to say the least.  This was a style really foreign to me and I was never really comfortable reading the book.  I kept waiting for something to happen.

Read it. Actually read it. I will bet you anything it's been assigned to you and you're thinking that you'll skip it, but just read it. Get through all of it, whether you hate it or love it. If you love it, bully for you. If you hate it, it'll get stuck in your head the rest of your life anyway. Hemingway is just that annoyingly good.

This is one of my favorite books of all time, and, together with A Moveable Feast why I love Hemingway so much. Here you can read a character review of the 'damned good-looking' Lady Brett Ashley in the Paris Review. http://www.theparisreview.org/blog/2012/07/19/character-studies-lady-brett-ashley/

column13: Great book-I love the Sun also Rises!
column14: I love this book! A great and witty book that could be read over and over!  It has every great karma and hemingway combination! Love to you! Cindy

The format and style of The Sun Also Rises contrasts greatly with many modern works.  Initially, I found the read to be difficult; however, I quickly warmed to the text.  I look forward to reading another of his works.
No problems with this order at all!! Book was in great condition!! Practically new! I will look buy again soon!!!

Here's how the story lines eventually unravel
Three men (at least or rather three and half) and one Le Femme Fatal
From Paris to Pamplona in escape from boredom for the leisure travel
Where they all drink Pernod Absinthe until she meets the boy, who boldly fights the bull
Jake acts as liaison arranging Brett-bullfighter sex affair
Cohn beats the guts of Spanish boy, Mike keeps on drinking and pretends that he's cool and doesn't care

I've read the book about his life in Paris and surrounding area, and this book was like reading something that wasn't fiction -- it seems like it was almost autobiographical.  And Hemingway DOES use a lot of conversation to let us get acquainted with the characters in his stories.

column13: I forgive you for "The Old Man and the Sea" , Ernest.
column14:
I can't quite fully explain this but this novel reminds me a little bit of "The Sheltering Sky" but if some of the principle characters weren't idiots unprepared for travel. Rational? No, but who cares?

I'd call this a cleanly crafted and damn good read. Some of the aspects of life that the book hints at were cutting edge in their acknowledgment for its day.

I am not going to give you a synopsis of the book, this is a review. If you really want to know what goes on read the blasted thing.

When you do I won't doubt that you'll find you'll want a cocktail since the characters dink on almost every page. You'll feel useless and energized at the same time and if you're an American, wanting to become an expat.

Pour yourself a good whiskey and soak it all in, just like the rocks you tossed in the tumbler.

This novel was enlightening and brilliant. Hemingway does an excellent job depicting the \\"lost generation\\" and the challenges they faced. I found myself intrigued by the tragic love story of Lady Ashley and Jake, and the realistic portrayal of their complicated lives was educational. I would highly reccomend this book.

In my recently published novel E Train to Masada which takes place in 1968, the main character compares Hemingway's lost generation of the 1920s to the protesters of the 1960s. While Hemingway's Jake Barnes in The Sun Also Rises has been made impotent by a WWI wound, he bears his fate with stoicism, dignity and even detachment, whereas the draft card and Vietnam medal burning protestors and soldiers of the `60s express pure rage. Hemingway's code of demonstrating manliness by standing one's ground \\"with grace\\" as the Cape Buffalo charges would be viewed as absurd and insane by the spectrum of 60's activists from students to professors to clerics to housewives.

Which is not to say Hemingway's people are ethically decent at all times. Robert Cohen is treated shabbily notwithstanding his Princeton education and championship boxing ability. Jake Barnes and his waspy cohort refer to Cohen's pushiness, hang-dog tagging along and even his nose in conversations both direct and implicit regarding his Jewishness. The bullying and belittling of Cohen to a significant degree drives the plot, making it impossible to avoid reading Cohen as a ready-made character that relieves Hemingway from the labor of character development. One also wonders if this shortcut reflects the author's personal view of Jews?

I have read The Sun Also Rises at least a half dozen times since the 60s but only lately have thoughts of the author as bully occurred. Which raises the question, do the attitudes of the times affect ones reaction to literature or does a text deemed great in one era succumb to cultural shifts in another?

Book looked brand new. I enjoyed reading
it very much. Hemmingway is a great writer.
It was a fun, light and interesting read. I would
recommend the book and the seller.

column13: Hemingway's Masterpiece - Surgically Precise Prose Never Flinching From The Painful Truth
column14:
I read \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" after reading \\"A Moveable Feast,\\" Hemingway's amazing factual account of his expatriate years in Paris with his \\"Paris Wife\\" Hadley, F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald, Ezra Pound, James Joyce, Gertrude Stein, and other members of the post-WWI \\"Lost Generation.\\" \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" is a novelization based on this Paris café society as well as on Hemingway's 1925 trip to Spain. It is an astonishing, riveting book. It is hard to believe that Hemingway wrote the first draft in two months, and that it was published when he was only 27 years old.

Jake Barnes is the narrator of the book, a working journalist with friends in the \\"Lost Generation\\" café society of Paris during the jazz age of the Roaring 20's. Jake suffered an unspecified wound during the Great War, rendering him impotent. Jake's true love is Lady Brett Ashley, a thoroughly modern woman who has been through two divorces and now has a new fiancé, Mike. Robert Cohn, a Jewish boxer and Bill Gorton, a novelist, round out the group of friends. They decide to attend the Festival of San Fermín in Pamplona, Spain and witness the \\"running of the bulls\\" and bullfighting firsthand. Cohn, who had an affair with Brett, is unable to contain his jealousy and the group slowly disintegrates.

The bullfighting scenes are breathtaking. Brett falls for the young matador Romero, and we see and learn to appreciate his artistry in the bull ring. The matador faces the existential nothingness in the charge of the bull, and puts down death with the thrust of his sword. Hemingway effectively contrasts the authenticity (living life fully) of bullfighting and of the working man (Jake), who continually pays the bills, with the inauthentic expatriates of the time living on inherited money. \\"Nobody ever lives their life all the way up except bull-fighters.\\"

In the terrific middle section of the book, which serves as a kind of interlude between The Paris and Pamplona sections, Jake and Bill go on a fishing trip in Spain. The bus trip with the Basques and the spare descriptions of the days at the river and the beautiful scenery is therapeutic for Jake and simply glows for the reader. It is all about the redemptive power of nature and is a rebirth of sorts for the two after the debauchery of Paris, after the horrors of war, and as \\"men without women.\\"

Hemingway always tried to write truthfully, and the book contains many quotes that stood out to me. Jake says, \\"It is awfully easy to be hard-boiled about everything in the daytime, but at night it is another thing.\\" An elderly gentleman called The Count observes, \\"It is because I have lived very much that now I can enjoy everything so well. That is the secret. You must get to know the values.\\" Also, when Brett talks about Mike she says, \\"He's so damned nice, and he's so awful. He's my sort of thing.\\"

Interestingly, the novel is a roman à clef, meaning that the characters and action are based on ones in the real world. Hemingway and his wife visited the festival in Pamplona for a third time in 1925 and took with them Hemingway's boyhood friend Bill Smith, Donald Ogden Stewart, Lady Duff Twysden (recently divorced), her lover Pat Guthrie, and Harold Loeb. \\"In Pamplona the group quickly disintegrated. Hemingway, attracted to Lady Duff, was jealous of Loeb, who had recently been on a romantic getaway with her; by the end of the week the two men had a public fistfight. Against this background was the influence of the young matador from Ronda, Cayetano Ordóñez, whose brilliance in the bullring affected the spectators. Ordóñez honored Hemingway's wife Hadley by presenting her, from the bullring, with the ear of a bull he killed. Outside of Pamplona, the fishing trip to the Irati River (near Burguete in Navarre) was marred by polluted water. Hemingway intended to write a non-fiction book about bullfighting but thought thatthe week's experiences had presented him with enough material for a novel.\\" Wikipedia contributors. \\"The Sun Also Rises.\\" Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, 4 Apr. 2013. Web. 24 Apr. 2013.

\\"The Sun Also Rises\\" is a masterpiece from Hemingway. He doesn't flinch from painful truths and trusts the reader to invest himself fully by filling in the blanks of his surgically precise prose. I think that \\"A Moveable Feast\\" is an excellent companion volume, giving the reader much factual background and \\"feel\\" for Hemingway's Paris years and insight into his writing process at that time. Characters from \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" leap off the page, peerlessly characterizing the \\"Lost Generation\\" between WWI and the Great Depression. Brett and Jake will stay with you always. \\"Isn't it pretty to think so.\\" Very highly recommended.aterial for a novel.\\" Wikipedia contributors. \\"The Sun Also Rises.\\" Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia, 4 Apr. 2013. Web. 24 Apr. 2013.

\\"The Sun Also Rises\\" is a masterpiece from Hemingway. He doesn't flinch from painful truths and trusts the reader to invest himself fully by filling in the blanks of his surgically precise prose. I think that \\"A Moveable Feast\\" is an excellent companion volume, giving the reader much factual background and \\"feel\\" for Hemingway's Paris years and insight into his writing process at that time. Characters from \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" leap off the page, peerlessly characterizing the \\"Lost Generation\\" between WWI and the Great Depression. Brett and Jake will stay with you always. \\"Isn't it pretty to think so.\\" Very highly recommended.

column13: Why is this book a classic??
column14: This book sucked!  I hated the characters. They were shallow, narcissistic drunks and whores.  And it had no plot.  It was basically a daily journal of some dude who likes to drink, fish, and go to bullfights.  I was planning on reading more Earnest Hemingway, but bumped him down on the list after this one.  I did end up reading A Farewell to Arms about a year later and it was much better.

column13: Fiction version of A Moveable Feast
column14: My obsession with Hemingway continues. Someone told me there was a lot of Hemingway the man in The Sun Also Rises. From what I've read, I think he put details about himself in Roger and Jake. The story was boring to me though. The characters were interesting and well developed, but nothing really happened, which usually doesn't bother me, but did here. Maybe because it was almost like rereading A Moveable Feast or The Paris Wife, bull fighting, Paris night life, heavy drinking, over and over. But I am still so intrigued by him, he is such a huge part of literary history.

This short novel does for the reader what good prose should: allows a perspective on an experience not easily had, and inspires some though and introspection. Also, I found I was inspired to drink more wine...
Can't say that it was as good as his later books.  But it was a reread for me.  Try it if you haven't already read it.

Hemingway is by far one of the greatest writers who ever lived.  His prose is simple, short and to the point.  \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" is NO exception.  Although his first novel, it is a precocious example of good things to come for this sad, troubled writer.  For the younger generation, if you've ever seen the film \\"Dazed and Confused\\", this book will not disappoint.  The characters jump right out of the book, and we've all had friends like these..shallow yet lost, fun but unloving, troubled but dependable.  Could not put it down for a second.  Can't wait to read \\"For whom the bell Tolls.\\"  Now, I'm going to get me a bottle of good absinthe...so I can dance the night away...Van Halen style.

column13: A Green, Preening Novel by a Nobel Laureate
column14: Let me begin by saying that I hold Hemingway in high esteem: so much so that while at the Key West Literary Seminar this year I visited his home for a second time. I have read nearly all of his novels and admire his devotion to writing insofar as he lived humbly in Paris among the Lost Generation to establish himself as a novelist. He paid his existential and literary dues as a novelist and was richly rewarded for his gifts. \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" is an early work and, although one can see his promise as a novelist, this particular novel suffers from a green, preening style, which may well the case of early autobiographically consuming novels. The book is taken from Hemingway's experiences in Paris on the Left Bank, the fiestas of Pamplona during the running of the bulls and fishing for trout in the mountains of Northern Spain. Despite the relative immaturity of his style he was an innovator: he was one of the early novelists to write dialogue with a truly sensitive ear attuned toward the ways in which ordinary people spoke to each other. He was committed to creating verisimilitude in dialogue and dialect. The characters cover themselves in their conversations with the slang of the day: \\"Women made such swell friends. Awfully swell. In the first place, (sic) you had to be in love with a woman to have a basis of friendship...The bill always came. That was one of the swell things you could count on.\\" One claim he makes, the truth of which may not be denied, is that we certainly pay for the things that we do: \\"You paid some way for everything that was any good.\\" So Hemingway produces a literary style for dialogue that is so readily played out in the novelists who follow him and becomes so advanced in its execution by them that a work like \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" almost seems a parody in many places. It must be one of the most quoted works in the Good Bad Hemingway Contest held annually which both praises and parodies his novels. He writes in criticism of another writer that \\"He's through... He's written about all the things he knows, and now he's on all the things he doesn't know.\\" Hemingway always wrote about the things that he knew from first-hand experience: war, fishing, writing, Cuba, Key West, the UP of Michigan, Paris, safari and women. Hem was a man of half as many wives as Henry VIII. Although he knew many women intimately, he didn't really understand them fully. I find that in many places Hemingway's women, even Lady Brett Ashley, play over and over again primarily as helpless objects of desire. In this book like most of his other characters Brett is a flat character and a stereotype for women of his era. I also found that other minorities (Jews, Afro-Americans) seem diminished in his work except for bull fighters and fishermen, essentially they are servants to a greater or lesser extent. Later in the \\"Old Man and the Sea\\" clearly this is not the case but it is true here in this book. He still has not yet really developed the sense of humanity which would emerge later to earn him a Nobel Prize for Literature. The male characters also seem flat with the Jewish boxer, Robert Cohn, and his hedonistic friends, Bill and the drunken Michael. He draws the bullfighter, Romero, a Spanish Romeo quite elegantly because he imbues in this character the deep respect Hemingway had for the courageous bullfighters and also portrays the bulls themselves as heroic, magnificent forces of nature, downstream like the great marlin, doomed by man's tragic desire to conquer and kill them for sport or sustenance as God similarly may play with mankind. Jake Barnes is a well drawn figure because he is Hemingway. It's as if Hemingway created Robert Cohn to be himself like a boxer, and Mike like the big drinker and the Hemingway women as the objects of desire that he sought. The book is poorly edited: I know, sorry, not withstanding Maxwell Perkins this is heresy but I stand by my claim. The stories about the fiesta at Pamplona and running of the bulls and the trout fishing and Brett with Romero weave a compelling tale worth reading. His writing about bull fighting and fishing attest to his fascination with both sports and elsewhere in hunting on safari. Then there is, of course, the elegant innuendo of the unfortunate war wound, one of the great scars of life for a man devoted to total immersion in his existential experience: none of us go through life without scars and a few may become immortal but rarely do we come out alive in the end. By all means read Hemingway but perhaps not this novel. Read the immortal works of Hemingway in \\"For Whom the Bell Tolls\\" and \\"A Farewell to Arms\\" and \\"The Old Man and the Sea\\" and \\"The Torrents of Spring\\" and even \\"Across the River and into the Trees\\" which impress me more as the Nobel Prize winner rather than the green, American newspaperman in Paris of the Lost Generation. Hemingway is an iconic American author whose simplicity of style and power in telling a story earned him vast wealth and reverence as a writer during and after his lifetime: what novelist worth his salt wouldn't want to come back in the next life as Hem?nd the trout fishing and Brett with Romero weave a compelling tale worth reading. His writing about bull fighting and fishing attest to his fascination with both sports and elsewhere in hunting on safari. Then there is, of course, the elegant innuendo of the unfortunate war wound, one of the great scars of life for a man devoted to total immersion in his existential experience: none of us go through life without scars and a few may become immortal but rarely do we come out alive in the end. By all means read Hemingway but perhaps not this novel. Read the immortal works of Hemingway in \\"For Whom the Bell Tolls\\" and \\"A Farewell to Arms\\" and \\"The Old Man and the Sea\\" and \\"The Torrents of Spring\\" and even \\"Across the River and into the Trees\\" which impress me more as the Nobel Prize winner rather than the green, American newspaperman in Paris of the Lost Generation. Hemingway is an iconic American author whose simplicity of style and power in telling a story earned him vast wealth and reverence as a writer during and after his lifetime: what novelist worth his salt wouldn't want to come back in the next life as Hem?

The book had no plot.  I kept expecting something to happen and nothing happened to hold my interest.  Mostly going to bars and fighting over Brett.  The part that was most interesting to me was when Brett met up with the bull fighter then Cohn got jealous and beat him up.

This quick and easy read by Hemingway has every element of a good book; drama, love, violence, and adventure!!! This book is quintessential Hemingway with his distinctive lack of punctuation between character dialogue. This book is short enough to make it a quick and easy read. The story also flows very well so that the reader does not get lost throughout the story.

I received this book and half way through it a few pages where doubled. i didn't think much at the time, then i got toward the end and the whole last chapter was the same as the one before. i ordered it from amazon, new. I Trusted in you Amazon, i feel betrayed :(

column13: Worst crap I ever read and that's putting it mildly!
column14: I was so bored reading this book.  After reading the grammatically incorrect sentences on the first page, I should have stopped. However, I was lulled by the great Hemingway name and continued onto the dull, dry book. It was so hard not editing his badly constructed sentences. They call this prose? Hah!!! No flow, no plot, not much in adventure and I could not wait to finish, just to see if anything was indeed worth the read. NOT! Don't waste your time and money. This book is worth starting a fire with or swatting a fly...that's all.

Ernest Hemingway's novel \\"The Sun Also Rises\\", about a scattered group of American expatriates living in Paris who travel to Spain, is a book that manages to deal with deep issues in a way that is subtle but unfortunately also frustratingly slow. The novel is short; at only 251 pages, it can be read in a few hours (although you'll want to read it slowly, since Hemingway packs so much into each short, declarative sentence). Despite it's length, reading the book is like alternating between running through mud and running on pavement. Sometime the prose is captivating, but at other times it is frustrating to deal with such annoying characters. How can Robert Cohn be so spineless? Why can't Brett Ashley understand that she's leading these men on? What is Jake trying to get out of pursuing Brett?

What I ended up enjoying most about the book, and contemplating for some time after, were the same things that annoyed me when reading. The characters are flawed, annoying, constantly giving in to emotion and self-indulgence, but these things make them real. I can compare them to people in my own life; I can imagine how these people actually are. Hemingway is able to successfully convey how these people are because he omits so much. If he described their appearances and antics with too much detail, they would become difficult to relate to, but by keeping them somewhat mysterious, like a new acquaintance, they become easier to understand and fit into what I know.

Unfortunately I cannot comment on how \\"The Sun Also Rises\\" compares to his other works. What I can say is that this work is possibly Hemingway's most well-known work about his time in Paris in the 1920's and many people recommended that I start with it. Hemingway's understanding of people and character is enthralling and makes the book a worthwhile read.

I am a Hemingway convert. I love how strong and clear his writing is. He only writes about the things that are beautiful and important to him, without really getting into his feelings. He simply states the facts, but from the facts he chooses to reveal and thoes he doesn't, you understand his perspective. It's remarkably sparse that way. The book was published in 1926 and it does have a slightly old-fashioned style about it - the colloquialisms people use, the slower pace, the things Hemingway and his friends do for fun - but the perspective is ageless. The focus on human beings and their interactions, irrespective of social class, education, nationality, is poetic and universal. I could (and probably will) read it again and again.
I really like this book!  It is a good read and I enjoy the content.  It was exactly what I was looking for!  I would recommend it to anyone looking for a good book!!

Having read it (and written about it ) in college plus the "Paris Wife" this summer,  together with the recent HBO special about Ernest and Martha, I thought it best to re-read it and see if my impressions of his work had changed with the years that had passes.  They didn't.  Still a great read.

column13: Review of The Sun Also Rises
column14: This is a good book about some artists (writers) after WW1 who have a lot of time on their hands. They drink and go on a trip to find some happiness. It is a look into life after WW1 about playboys or aspiring writers in Europe.
I had not read Hemingway since I was a kid, what a great story!  Reading this was like having a movie play in my mind. The imagery was amazing!  Highly recommend!

Just a book about a few friends hanging out and all the stuff that happens to them. No explosions. No crazy mysteries to solve. No car chases. No bombs to diffuse or world to save. No complex love triangles. It's all really rather mundane. It's basically Seinfeld/Entourage in the 1920s. It's a book about nothing.

I love this book because it reminds me of my times with my friends--road trips, bars, clubs, hangovers, girl troubles, lazy summer days, etc. It's not the specific details in the book, but the interactions of the characters that strikes a familiar chord.

This book is classic Hemingway: simple, but surprisingly rich and engaging. Like I said, it's a book about nothing, but as you turn that last page, you can't help but feel as though you've been hanging out with them all along. You don't want the road trip to end.
Hemingway's simplistic  style is surprizingly hypnotic. It's subtle ride, gives way for the reader to use their own imagination into the heart and soul of the story.

column13: The Obsessive Pursuit of Shallow Beauty in the Roaring Twenties
column14:
The Sun Also Rises survives as a classic as much because of Hemingway's radical departure in writing style as for the content that made the book an immediate popular success in 1926. It roared into the Roaring Twenties and Prohibition, a generation reeling from the disillusionment of World War I and ready for liberation from suffocating Victorian social strictures and the existing cumbersome florid literary style.

The Sun Also Rises appeals especially to the young hedonist whose parents never \\"did it\\" in daytime and felt guilty if they did it for any purpose but procreation. The book gushes with drinking scenes that tantalized alcohol-parched Americans whose access to liquor had been severely restricted for years. The characters behave less like mature adults than kids who've just reached drinking age.

If the appeal of booze and an airy new way of writing weren't enough, Brett Ashley, the female lead and possibly the first truly liberated woman in American literature, ensured the book's success. In the United States, women had in 1920 only just acquired the right to vote. And here was a beautiful mature woman enjoying unmarried sex with serial partners of her choosing while wearing a man's hat and short hair. What a seismic shock to conservative Midwestern values.

Hemingway was only twenty-four when he wrote The Sun Also Rises. He'd barely begun to live. At eighteen he'd spent a mere five weeks in military uniform before he was injured, convalesced in a hospital and got sent home. How could a twenty-four-year-old who'd never even been to college know much worth writing about other than his war experience, which the book hardly mentions? Perhaps there's an answer in the way Hemingway hurled himself at life. Life excited him. He lived the hedonistic lifestyle for which so many post-Victorian readers hungered. But he also reflected on himself and the behavior of those around him and wrote about what he noticed.

It's interesting that both The Sun Also Rises and The Great Gatsby are about young men obsessing over beautiful but shallow women and were written at about the same time (Feb '25 for Gatsby and Oct '26 for TSAR) by two young men who were had been close friends.

[May contain spoilers]Synopsis: Three expatriate American writers, Jake, Bill and Cohn, rendezvous in Paris before leaving on a holiday trip to the bullfight fiesta in Pamplona, Spain, accompanied by a beautiful British divorcee and her new beau, Michael, also a Brit. Jake narrates the story and is in love with Brett but impotent due to his war injury. She professes to be in love with Jake but they are not intimate. On the way to Pamplona, Jake and Bill go fishing and Cohn goes off to be seduced by Brett.

In Pamplona there is a lot of drinking and misbehaving and they attend the bull-fights. Brett becomes enamored with a champion young matator, Romero, and seduces him. Cohn, jealous, confronts them and severely beats Romero, who must go into the ring the next day despite his injuries. Cohn also fights with the other two Americans. Brett runs off with Romero for an affair and a week later expels him and calls Jake to help her reunite with Michael.

Jake's impotency is a twist that doesn't seem to have much purpose other than to neutralize the narrator by insulating him from being a full-on competitor to Cohn for Brett's affections. Jake's neutered status does pique the curiosity. Perhaps it stems from Hemingway's experience convalescing in hospital from the war injuries that handicapped him temporarily in bed. (Brett's complaints of being sexually frustrated may have originated with Hemingway's nurse and paramour, Agnes.)

The Sun Also Rises is about the emptiness of idle self-indulgence. Through the voice of Jake Barnes, Hemingway expresses his groping quest for meaning and morality. The book holds up the mirror to a group of misbehaving expatriates and says, \\"Here, look at yourselves!\\"
An absurd premise for the book might be that immorality is whatever makes you feel guilty:
[Jake, drunk and narrating] \\"...I wished Mike would not behave so terribly to Cohn, though. ...I liked to see him hurt Cohn. I wished he would not do it, though, because afterward it made me disgusted at myself. That was morality; things that made you disgusted afterward. No, that must be immorality.\\" Is this the musing of a drunkard or are we supposed to take it seriously?

Throughout the book, Jake gropes into moral territory, reflecting the view that life is just a series of transactions, this-for-that value exchanges. This view appears six or seven times, on pages 34, 67, 78, 152-153, 156, & 237.
Brett (p.34): \\"'Don't we pay for all the things we do? ...When I think of the hell I've put chaps through. [meaning torturing men with her provocative sexuality] I'm paying for it now.'\\" [meaning she's the one now being tortured by denial of sexual relations with Jake, whom she professes to love, due to his impotency.] The operative phrase here is \\"we pay for all the things we do.\\"

The values concept appears next during a string of scenes involving Count Mippipopolous (pp. 60-71):
[The Count] \\"'You see, Mr. Barnes, it is because I have lived very much that now I can enjoy everything so well. Don't you find it like that?' [He feels he's earned the right to enjoy life. He's entitled because he's paid his dues.]

'Yes. Absolutely.' [Jake]

`I know,' said the count. `That is the secret. You must get to know the values.'

`Doesn't anything ever happen to your values?' Brett asked.

`No. Not any more.'

`Never fall in love?'

`Always,' said the count. `I am always in love.'

`What does that do to your values?'

`That, too, has got a place in my values.'

`You haven't any values. You're dead, that's all.'

`No, my dear. You're not right. I'm not dead at all.'\\"

Here the theory of life as a series of transactions, value for value, is asserted by the Count and Jake agrees. Brett probes for a weak spot in the theory, implying that love trumps everything, but the Count sticks by his assertion that suffering (he's been to war and is battle scarred) entitles one to appreciate the good life.

The values theme appears next on page 78: [Bill] \\"`...Simple exchange of values. You give them money. They give you a stuffed dog.'

`We'll get one on the way back.' [Jake]

`All right. Have it your own way. Road to hell paved with un-bought stuffed dogs.'\\"

This is a minor repetition of the theme, hardly worth mentioning except as a reminder that sometimes the exchange of values may seem out of balance.

Having prepared the reader, Hemingway next takes the philosophy of the value exchange much deeper on page 152:

[Jake, narrating] \\"I had been having Brett for a friend. I had not been thinking about her side of it. I had been getting something for nothing. That only delayed the presentation of the bill. The bill always came. That was one swell thing you could count on.

I thought I had paid for everything. Not like the woman pays and pays. No idea of retribution or punishment. Just exchange of values. You gave up something and got something else. Or you worked for something. You paid some way for everything that was any good. I paid my way into enough things that I liked, so that I had a good time. Either you paid by learning about them, or by experience, or by taking chances, or by money. Enjoying living was learning to get your money's worth and knowing when you had it. [emphasis added] You could get your money's worth. The world was a good place to buy in. It seemed like a fine philosophy. In five years, I thought, it will seem just as silly as all the other fine philosophies I've had.

Perhaps that wasn't true, though. Perhaps as you went along you did learn something. I did not care what it was all about. All I wanted to know was how to live in it. Maybe if you found out how to live in it you learned from that what it was all about.\\"

The above passage includes an outright declaration of Jake's transactional theory as the \\"...exchange of values. You gave up something and got something else.\\" What could be more clear?

Next Jake applies his transactional theory to the mundane act of reading a book (p. 153):

[Jake, narrating, drunk]\\"I knew that now, reading it in the over-sensitized state of my mind after much too much brandy, I would remember it somewhere, and afterward it would seem as though it had really happened to me. I would always have it. That was another good thing you paid for and then had.\\"

On page 156 is another reflection on life as exchange transactions:

[Jake, narrating about the peasants] \\"They had come in so recently from the plains and the hills that it was necessary that they make their shifting in values gradually. They could not start in paying cafe prices. They got their money's worth in the wine-shops. Money still had a definite value in hours worked and bushels of grain sold. Late in the fiesta it would not matter what they paid, nor where they bought.\\"

This is another minor reference to values, reinforcing the transactional concept.

On page 237 the values concept is mentioned one last time before the meaning of the book is fully revealed in the denoument:

[Jake, narrating, about being back in France] \\"It felt comfortable to be in a country where it is so simple to make people happy. ...Everything is on such a clear financial basis in France. It is the simplest country to live in. No one makes things complicated by becoming your friend for any obscure reason. If you want people to like you you have only to spend a little money. I spent a little money and the waiter liked me. He appreciated my valuable qualities. He would be glad to see me back.\\"

In the denoument, after musing repeatedly throughout the book on life as a series of value exchanges, Hemingway presents thirty-four-year-old Brett after her fling with the nineteen-year-old matador, threatening his career. She mentions repeatedly how good or \\"set-up\\" she feels after her conquest, which also destroyed Jake's dearly earned reputation among the afficiones of Pamplona. Her other sexual conquest led to fistfights among the men of her party, destroying their friendships. In this aftermath of destruction, Brett can think only of herself. (Beginning on page 248):

\\"`You know,\\" Brett said, \\"he'd only been with two women before. He never cared about anything but bull-fighting.'

`He's got plenty of time.'

`I don't know. He thinks it was me. Not the show in general.' [meaning the fiesta they attended]

`Well, it was you.'

`Yes. It was me.'

`I thought you weren't going to ever talk about it.'

`How can I help it?'

`You'll lose it if you talk about it.'

`I just talk around it. You know I feel rather damned good, Jake.'

`You should.'

`You know it makes one feel rather good deciding not to be a bitch.'\\" [meaning she's done Romero the young matador a favor by making him leave]

Brett has been going on and on to Jake about her affair with Romero and she's just reduced the entire \\"transaction\\" between herself and Romero to a one-sided evaluation of how good it has made her feel. It's been all about her, with no apologies for the damage caused by her narcissistic ego gratification. She then turns her attention to Jake and how good he could have made her feel if things were different: \\"'Oh, Jake,' Brett said, `we could have had such a damned good time together.'\\"

But Jake has wised up: \\"'Yes,' I said. `Isn't it pretty to think so.'\\"

From Brett's angle, life is a string of transactions skewed in her favor. She's drunk. Jake's drunk. What are we supposed to make of the musings of drunkards?

The book ends in logical exhaustion. The misbehaving characters will keep misbehaving. Jake may have a clearer view of Brett, but there's no sign he'll not respond to her the same way next time.

Brett seems quite pleased with herself, even though she's behaved badly. Is this supposed to prove the converse of the theory that what's immoral is that which makes us feel disgusted?

The book presents a segment of society who have lost their moral compass and don't know it, nor do they seem to care. Jake is groping for meaning with his transactional theory, but he's far from reaching any conclusion.

Jake, who mirrors young Hemingway, reminds us of Holden Caulfield in The Catcher in the Rye and John Galt in Atlas Shrugged, young minds struggling toward an existential paradigm. An identity. Atlas Shrugged gives a simple solution: to hell with Jake's \\"tit for tat,\\" do only what is in your self interest.

But self-interest is in direct conflict what we are taught in the Judeo-Christian world: do unto others as you would have done unto you and love thy neighbor as thyself. Holden describes his angst arising from struggling for a value system that gives relief from \\"all the phonies,\\" the rampant hypocrisy of the adult world confronting him.

Jake's transactional theory is a modest attempt at a personal philosophy, but he's much more like Holden than Galt, (both of whom were'nt around until the 1950s.)

I was a little disappointed in the overall impact of the book, having read that it was Hemingway's greatest novel. I'd read three of his others and his memoir, A Moveable Feast, and over thirty of his short stories. I felt pulled along not so much by the novel's characters or plot as by my expectations, which were perhaps unreasonably high.

The plot was circular. Like The Oddsey and The Canterbury Tales, a journey, an adventure. No great obstacle was overcome or goal achieved. The characters were mostly flawed and notably un-heroic. Jake, the narrator, seemed flat. He didn't share many emotions and he reported on the externals of the other characters with detachment.

In the end though, by wising up to being used by Brett, he was the only character who changed. The narrative voice was the best part, authoritative, nimble, flowing like music. A pleasure to read.

And so my rating:

Memorable 4
Socially Relevant 5
Informative 3
Unique 5
Thought Provoking 4
Well Written/Expressed 4
Entertaining 4
Inspires Visualization 3
Sparks Emotion 4
Life Changing 3

Hemingway is Hemingway. The writing is clean and economic and always gets its point across. Lean and sturdy. Something like Kerouac with more clarity and ease. He seems to effortlessly draw up such vivid imagery. I think it's in the negative space but he manages to leave me drooling for his world.
Hemingway is himself a hero of American literature for many reasons.

The Sun Also Rises is my favorite Hemingway novel. There's something about his succinct style and the details that he chooses to focus on that mesmerizes me. Ashley is an interesting character, and I loved the setting. Paris in the 1920s is fascinating. The bullfighting was kind of hard for me because I love animals. The society around the bullfighting and drinking was interesting for me. I've always been curious how much of this novel was autobiographical and how much was pure fiction. I used to have a Hemingway biography on vhs. I guess it's time to see if it's available on dvd. If anyone knows a good Hemingway biography that talks about whether this book was autobiographical, please comment and let me know.
This novel is classic, it has all the intrigue of of the novel of today. It is fine example of how writing has evolved into what it is today.

column13: The Sun Also Rises".  Hemingway is an all time great author; anything he wrote is superb.
column14: Hemingway is an all time great author; anything he wrote is superb. I would recommend it to anyone, especially students of history.

column13: Hemingway's classic being enjoyed by my husband
column14: My husband had never read this classic, and is enjoying it, altho he finds it it to be about the 1920s.  It is written in the first person by an author living in France and the last half of the book is about his visit to Spain during bullfighting week.  My husband says he feels the "story is dragged out" but this known famous writer is interesting, and it's good to be acquainted with one of his most famous books.  He enjoyed the author's A  Moveable Feast much more because this concentrates on France in the 1920s and devotes a few chapters to Scott Fitzgerald, which made it more interesting. to him.

This novel, more a novella, did not meet my expectations, especially being aware that Hemingway considered it his most accomplished book. There is too much dialogue, he is not \\"at his best\\" in his descrption of the fishing day in Basque country, or the Basque country, or the bull-fights. His novel comes off, as a character in A Moveable Feast told him of his Literature, too, skinny, too sinewy. Also, it is brutally anti-semitic.

I think this is my fourth or fifth time to read this novel, and each time I read it I had an entirely different impression. In high school, the group of expatriates visiting Spain seemed glamorous and tragic, the dialog hard to follow.

Now I see the book more as having historical significance. Hemingway captured \\"The Lost Generation\\" in these pages. His use of terse, journalistic prose was revolutionary. However, with age, the characters drunken escapades seem pathetic and juvenile rather that funny and glamorous. I feel certain this will be my last time to read it.... I'm too old for this crap.
This book came in as I had expected it too be as well as on time! Very happy with this purchase!!

I am an avid reader but I had never read Hemingway before. I don't get it. This book read like a ten year old wrote it. I realize this was written when hex was in his 20's and this was supposedly a new writing style but it sure didn't feel like a modern classic. JMOO.

column13: How can a story of a Eunuch and a sexually loose woman be boring?
column14:
You'd think that a story centered on a Eunuch who loves a sexually liberal woman would be enjoyable, but it's not. Hemmingway's first novel, The Sun Also Rises, is anticlimactic and uninteresting, however his writing style is a treat, which leads me to the conclusion that although Hemmingway had a talent for writing effective sentences, at this point in his career he hadn't quite become a good storyteller.

The story brought the reader along on a ride of people with money, no morality to drive them, too much time on their hands and a bordom of what to do with themselves. So the story is essentially made up of the characters going to clubs, and restaurants, arguing/joking in a drunken stupor and then eventually deciding to go do the same thing during the bullfights in Spain. That may sound interesting but in Spain it's the same story, they do nothing new, and there is no climax. The only thing close to a climax is that Brett cheats on Michael with another man, but the way he describes their interaction is dull and he doesn't present it in a way that hooks you. It was way too obvious and you knew it was coming.

As for the writing, there is a lot to learn from. In some ways it shows how impactful terse sentences can be. There were times when I was caught off guard by the imagery that came to mind through his simple statements, but that can only be appreciated for so long. The long descriptions of Spanish countryside for instance made an already slow story come to a complete halt.

So to sum it up, the story is slow and nothing that anyone in LA or modern times hasn't seen a million times over. The one thing I find interested is that I didn't realize that society then was so similar to society today: so hopeless, hedonistic and foolish in nature. Let me put it this way, if you aren't looking to be entertained, but would like literary insight on creating terse, yet impactful sentences, then this is the book for you. The book is a piece of history in Hemmingway's career when he hadn't quite found something interesting to say, but it's interesting none-the-less because of the way he says it.

A meandering novel with many meaningless conversations that really don't amount to very much. There were a few high-lights - the bull-fighting scenes towards the end were, I suppose, vintage Hemingway. Also the setting at the fishing village (or vacation spot) had the beginnings of some introspection, but was not taken very far. The first one hundred pages in Paris were repetitive and bland.

In The Sun Also Rises, Ernest Hemingway describes aimless, jaded and wounded characters and their efforts to numb these feelings of emptiness by leading idle lives of excess. Hemingway's great talent is that he shows these complicated emotions with his classic clean and simple writing style.

There are endless back and forth exchanges between the narrator Jake Barnes, Robert Cohn, Lady Brett Ashley, Mike Campbell and the people they meet in Paris and in Pamplona. Hemingway tells his story through these seemingly insignificant conversations and Jake's narration where we discover important things about each character. We learn how Jake is still struggling to accept his war injury and understand his relationship with Brett. We see how Robert Cohn becomes more and more shunned as he pursues Brett. And with every one of Brett's reckless relationships with the men who surround her, particularly Mike and the bullfighter Pedro Romero, we discover her own feelings of a lost life.

I particularly liked how Hemingway took his description of Cohn on the very first page of the book and directly tied it to Cohn's exploding temper in Pamplona. I saw hope in Jake's bitter-sweet relationship with Brett despite the overwhelmingly hopeless theme of the story.

column13: An exceedingly complicated work to review
column14:
\\"The Sun Also Rises\\" is Hemingway's first novel. It has some first novel problems, namely issues with structure in certain places. There are digressions that really aren't that important, and as hard as the author tries to understate matters, some things are beaten into your head and other details, important details, are surprisingly easy to miss.
